text: The sandwiches were amazing.  My friend and I ordered the soppressata and the tomato, basil, mozzarella to share.  The sandwiches were so fresh.  The ingredients tasted crispy and complimented very well.  I understand the limited menu is so that they can focus on producing less at greater quality but I am so curious to see what else they could put together.  And I kinda wish there was a little more shade outside in the eating area.  It happened to be a hot day amd my cream soda got warm fast and eating a hot sandwich in the sun isn't so easy.

Goin here is always a treat, especially since the sweets for the end is always a surprise.  I love the mozzarella sandwhich and the people who work there are always so nice.  Can't wait for more choices from them...  more choices?
Absolutley fantastic meal! Everything handmade onsite and fresh! By far one of the best the best meals I've ever had! Coming back tomorrow for lunch! Amazing service as well!

This is by far the best pizza I have ever had in my life hands down :) We order the pizza rosa that had red onions and pistachios. It was amazing! We also had the flourless chocolate cake and that was amazing too! I will definitely be back! The ambiance was very cool as well!

Pane Bianco is the place I go when I want a great, random sandwich.  A lot of people I take there their time are thrown off by the limited "standard" menu, but I think the stand-by's are great, and the idea of trying a new sandwich/flavor-profile imagined by the chef is fantastic.  

Price:  Not bad
Service: Good
Atmosphere:  Great
Food:  Great

While slightly more costly than I'd pay for a typical sandwich lunch, it's worth the cost.  If the place wasn't situated just far enough north of Downtown to make it a trip, I'm sure I'd go here at least 1-2x a week.

My girlfriend took me here when I came to visit from LA, promising me a world class sandwich experience.  Now, I'm not TRYING to be condescending (although I undoubtedly will come off that way), but the place was MEH.

The selection of sandwiches from the menu was pathetic (I counted 3 or 4 varieties in total), the decor screamed 'we're trying to be hip, modern, and upscale yet can't conceal the pathetic, unattractive, and disorganized environment behind the counter', and the employees took far too much pride for what I got: A yummy, average sandwich.  The bread was  freshly made and good (nothing to rave about coming from LA), the mozarella/basil/tomato were all good (the best part), and the couple bucks extra for added meat was wholly unworth it, as it detracted from the delicious elements (cheese and veggies) and was a pathetic portion.

The bottom line: Good sandwich, bad selection, overly pretentious/hyped.  I can name 20 places in LA off the top of my head that match and EXCEED, on all fronts, this bastion of pretend. That being said, when in Phoenix I'd gladly pony up 9 bucks for the plain ol' mozzarella-tomato-basil sandwich (sans meat), though I'd rather stop by Delux (fantastic burgers and fries at great prices) and avoid feeling annoyed/perturbed by this place's smugness.

Years ago, I remember hearing Chris Bianco say he was searching around for a kitchen in town where he could bake bread and do some occasional cooking. How lucky for us Valley folk that he took that idea a couple steps further and opened a lunch spot.

And, boy, does he bake bread here - that's what makes the sandwiches at Pane Bianco unforgettable. It's like ciabatta meets pita bread in a wood-fired oven - and every bit as good as his pizza dough. Add to that some of the best meats, cheeses and other deliciousness available and you've got one heck of a great sandwich. 

I'm usually partial to whatever the market sandwich happens to be - especially the prosciutto, sausage or braseola - though the always-on-the-menu sopressata can be every bit as tasty (note: sometimes the salami is sliced really thick and I prefer thinner slices; also the red peppers are great, but I kind of miss the olive tapenade they use to use.)

Focaccia here is also a don't miss and flavors change daily. I think it's best when there's tomato, caramelized onions and a hard cheese; definitely asked for it warmed up. Not a big fan of the lemon rosemary, but I'm sure that appeals to some palates. 

I've only had a salad once, never the tuna, so I can't really say much about those, except that I'm sure the ingredients and flavor combinations are top-notch - wouldn't be in a Bianco restaurant otherwise. That's why I always come back for more...

My husband and I went to Pane Bianco when we were driving through Phoenix and we absolutely loved it! Incredible food, service and decor. Pane Bianco had a very warm and friendly vibe. The bread is to die for!

After reading the reviews, I was expecting more. Pane Bianco is okay. It is a little expensive for what you get. I had the tomato, basil, and mozzarella sandwich for lunch. The mozzarella slab was huge and disproportionate to the tomato and basil. It was just too much of one flavor. I feel lucky that I had someone to trade sandwiches with halfway through the meal. The tuna was okay though nothing special. The iced tea was good, and I appreciate that.  It is often hard to find decent iced tea.  I also enjoyed the rice pudding.  I would try Pane Bianco again, but I think it will always be too much of the same flavor.

A friend was told that he had to leave the restaurant because he was speaking Spanish and it was an "English Only dining area." This place is foul. See the picture added above. It is so disappointing to know that when Arizona takes 2 steps forward an establishment like this brings it 5 steps back. Disgraceful.

I went to Pane Bianco for the first time a few days ago for a quick lunch. I choose the market special (the special of the day). The chicken sandwich was delicious, rich in taste and the bread was nicely crunchy! Da provare!!! You have to try it! They also sell bread; I tried two different kind, both amazing!
The atmosphere at Pane Bianco is friendly and welcoming. Great food, excellent quality and unique interior design!

Possibly in the coolest area of Phoenix!

Left side of restaurant= eating in
Right side= eating on patio Or ordering out.

Don't get confused on that

MMMMMMM.. sandwiches......

Anytime I hear mention of pane bianco.. my mouth waters.  That remarkably simple and successful formula that has made Pizzeria Bianco so famous, has once again been executed to perfection in this little restaurant off of central.  
They are only open for lunch(  11am-3pm), and I recommend avoiding stopping by during the height of lunch hour.  On a side note, there is no indoor dining.  Seating is limited to wooden tables and benches out front that are shared with the customers of Lux. 

I always introduce friends and co-workers to this place.  and everytime we leave its the same reaction.... Wow!  During my last visit to Pane Bianco, I took a co-worker who had never been there.  while we were waiting, the owner comes rolling in with a basket of fresh veggies that looked amazing.  Does he grow this in his garden?  Did he sign a deal with the devil?  I dont know how he does it.  

I usually go for the Mozzarella, Local Tomato & Basil sandwich.  This thing is crazy delicious.  And when people say fresh, they mean it.  Its perfect and the bread is insanely delicious (chewy and crunchy all at the same time).  The same goes for any sandwich you might choose here.
Also, if you love to just chow on some fresh baked bread like I do, grab a baguette.  they are $3 and can't be beat.

This place is a winner and you will be glad you tried it

My dad and I shared a salami sandwich here a few weeks back, the bread is amazing I think they make it in house. It is very casual and pleasant I am planning my next meal there. Also enjoyed rice pudding and flourless chocolate cake. their french press coffee is from Lux. Yes and yes. They have a cute little room that would be fun for a private party. Furniture and decorations kitch/fun.

First time trying this place today almost looks like one of those hole in the wall places from the outside but going inside its nice, me and the wife ordered the mozerella tomato basil sandwich....sooo good the bread is amazing the sandwich is so simple but works so well together. Definitely recommend this to who haven't tried it.

Great lunch!  Mozzarella was wonderful. The handmade bread was delicious. Started off with some "Bites"  pickled veggies and fresh made green olives. The market salad and sandwich that my husband and I shared was delicious.

 Overall the quality, freshness and taste was superb. Our server was friendly and helpful. Even though it is quite a drive for us we will be back soon.

From their specials (the prosciutto cotto, sloppy guiseppi and spicy pulled chicken), to their house made mozzarella, basil and red ripe tomato sandwhiches and awesome salads, you can't go wrong. 

All of their ingredients are locally sourced (whenever possible) and define farm to table in Phoenix.

Their fresh, wood fired bread adds what Phoenix needs... and wants. I love this place so much, I go at LEAST once a week.

The prices are a little more than you'd pay at a chain. But I would rather have the freshness you don't get at a chain for a few extra pennys. Plus, keep your money local.

The place is hip, relaxed and inviting. Take a quick trip over and enjoy a bite to eat. 

And if you're looking for something to take with you, they offer a wide selection of pastas, oils, fresh dried herbs and Bianco's own line of stewed tomatoes that will make your next pot of sauce an awesome memory. 

Oh, and grab a couple of fresh baked wood fired loaves to finish off that home made sauce and pasta. The perfect meal for the folks on the go.

If you've eaten at Pizzeria Bianco, you already have an understanding of how much care and attention the folks at Pane Bianco will give to your sandwich. Today's market sandwich was filled with textured goat cheese, roasted tomatoes, and arugula -- delicious. Each sandwich comes with a small piece of candy for dessert (which, if you're like me, you'll eat on the way out the door). 

While the sandwiches are great, here's the beauty of Pane Bianco -- you can purchase loaves of the house bread served at Pizzeria Bianco for $3 each. I've never had better bread than this. Period. I'll be picking up a loaf the next time I make Nigella's trout pate (http://www.notquitenigella.com/2008/01/22/smoked-trout-pate-from-nigella-express/).

This is why you should not wait to write reviews. I've totally forgotten what I had here. I remember it was a sandwich and I remember it was delicious. I remember it made me want to go back for seconds only so I could try other things from the menu since I wouldn't likely be back anytime soon. I remember that the staff was super nice and friendly. I remember the outdoor seating area was a bit of a cluster for folks dining solo - it's basically just a bunch of wooden benches that deal better with groups. I remember I bookmarked it for review on yelp. I remember I wanted to kick myself when I started to write this review and couldn't remember what I ate here.

Another new restaurant for me....met a friend here and got the soprassata (not sure I spelled that correctly), oh and a Mountain Spring Water in a green glass bottle.  

Cute little place and I like going to non-chain businesses so already a star. But I don't think I could go during our "winter" when there's no place inside to sit.  When I went it was sunny as usual but the chilly wind made the experience a little less desirable.

The sandwich - it was good, liked the crusty but chewy bread and it wasn't too thick or hard. The ingredients were also tasty - simple but tasty - my kind of sandwich.  The sandwiches came out super quick which was nice during lunch time.  

Although I liked the place and would probably go back sometime, I doubt it's at the top of my "to go" places. Little on the pricey and shi-shi side. I wanted a water - expecting bottled water of course  - but when I got asked "spring or still?"  and I was thrown off.  I just want a friggin water. Then it comes in a totally foreign container....I'm a simple girl and just want simple water.
Great food for hipsters. No really, the food is genuinely great. Had the fennel salad, and discovered a new vegetable: watermelon radish???
The ambience is great. Highly recommend the sopprassata sandwich and the Italian ices (especially the pear brandy)

It's all about the bread. With bread this mind-blowingly delicious, who cares what's in between?! I've only had the mozzarella, tomato, and basil sandwich...I keep going back to it because I love it so much...but I'm sure the others are as terrific because of the amazing bread. Nowhere to sit indoors, so grab it to go when the weather's hot, or enjoy the outdoor patio when it's cool. Having Lux next door for gourmet coffee, pastries, and more is a big plus.

We found this place through yelp for lunch, and its great !  Its small, rustic, large tables for seating.. It was not too busy when we went, so we were to able to chat with our server regarding the place. She was friendly and informed us of their dinner menus, also we learned they serve the same pizza as Pizzeria Bianco without the long wait. The service was fantasitic. 

That day  we ordered the vegertarian soup to share. OMG ! I could eat that every day, so hearty and delicous. My husband who is not a big fan of soups, loved it. 
We both also ordered the Mozzarella, tomato basil sandwiches. Fresh mozzeralla,  fresh bread, simple and delicous, the slaw/salad it was served with  was beyond amazing. 

We will return to try their dinner menu soon !

I award two stars because the bread is, indeed, fantastic.  Other than that, I was underwhelmed by the pretentiousness.  The decor is painfully cute.  No, this is not what casual but sophisticated places look like in Europe, although communal tables are common overseas.  The menu is very limited and each dish seems designed to wow with an ingredient one wouldn't expect.  Why not just make something that tastes good?  Why does it have to be "different" just to be "different"?  

I had the chicken salad.  The chicken was good but there wasn't much of it.  It was somewhat overwhelmed by mustard and the rest of the salad consisted of a pile of arugula and dates.  Forgive me if I sound like a rube for never experiencing dates with mustard before.  But I won't be doing it again.  If the pizzas available at Pizzeria Bianco are also made here, that wasn't clear from the menu the day I visited.  There was a pizza of the day, again with some unusual addition designed to turn heads.  I'm sure the ingredients such as the fresh herbs and house-made mozzarella are superb here as they are in Bianco's other establishments, but they SHOULD BE given the prices.  

Get the bread to go.  Otherwise the main reason to dine here is to be seen somewhere that Phoenicians who never leave the Southwest think is European.

Love this place! Farm fresh fruit and veggies. Desserts and bread made from scratch. The pizza is the best in the city. Daily quality control is recognized and appreciated. Art work for the most part has been done by family members of the owners. Establishment supports local growers and brewers. Meat is from happy grass feed animals. Highly recommend you stop in and say hello to John and Armando who are always on site. One last piece of information some will appreciate: It does not feel like a corporate "look at me, I'm here" type of restaurant. People who eat at this place understand the value of nutritional food that tastes awesome. The only negative is that the parking lot is shared with Lux Cafe and at times parking is a problem.
Awesome place! Love the revolving menu. The Tres leche w rhubarb was to die for. Highly recommend it!

I went on a Saturday afternoon near closing - at 3 PM! If the wait had been long, there would have been some serious star lossage. The hours are exceedingly lame. 

The interior is pleasant and clearly well-contemplated. The wood-fired oven is massive and center-stage as it ought to be. Just as the center piece of all of the food here is the freshly baked bread. 

The selection of sandwiches was lame. I believe there were three. They are all basically salads on bread. Healthy, simple, and fresh, yes. Satisfying variety, no. 

I got the Caprese. It was very good. Of course, the crispy, perfect bread, fresh buttery mozzarella, and fragrant basil was a scrumptious melange. The salad greens and oil was lame-o-rific. Bland oil dressing. 

Expensivo. 

I wish there were more restaurants like this - competition would breed better prices, better hours, and more selections. 

I'll be back if I DON'T have to wait in line.   Update - back again several times.  Always fantastic.  Only want to take off 1/2 star lamenting lack of variety.  I do respect the KISS method - keep it simple, stupid.

Go to Lux and get a killer hot chocolate, tea, chai, or coffee.

A great cup of coffee from Lux next door and a beautifully prepared sandwich from Pane makes for a *gold star* afternoon. I had the sopressata which is with salami and cheese. 

Sandwiches are $8-- a bit pricey, but worth it.

Great place to for for lunch. The sandwiches were delicious, we had the mozzarella with tomato and basil one as well as Sopresetta. There was plenty of seating arrangements outside but i'm imagining during rush time there won't be a whole lot left. 
Great atmosphere and had lots of parking too.

It's a good thing I don't work in Central Phoenix - I would stop by Pane Bianco WAY too often. This tiny sandwich shop is like nothing I've experienced before in Phoenix. They specialize in a very limited menu of artisanal sandwiches, served on house-made bread, as well as a few salads. I've had all of the sandwiches and have narrowed the top two down to the soppressata and the tuna.  The soppressata is like an Italian sandwich on gourmet steroids. The roasted red peppers bring out the rich flavors of the Italian meats and provide the perfect acidic balance to the fattier density of the meats and cheese. A perfect foil to the soppressata, the tuna is light and delicate with a strong lemon flavor - this isn't you mom's canned tuna and Miracle Whip on white bread. The tuna, made with red onion, lemon and olives, is topped with wild arugula, which provides a bitter bite and counters the fishiness. My suggestion - go with a friend and order one of each. The sandwiches are large, and I love to order one tuna and one soppressata and split half-and-half. 

I've heard nothing but great reviews for the salads, too, but I confess that I'm never in the mood the healthy salad alternative when I can smell freshly baked bread and know that a fabulous Pane Bianco sandwich creation is in my immediate future.
Fantastic ! This place never disappoints. The food is incredible and the owners brother is always so friendly and warm to the patrons. Highly recommend it! Great food incredible atmosphere!
They have the best sandwiches in Phoenix, also their tres leches cake is outstanding. love this place

This place is definitely the jewel of Bianco's reign of terror. Skip the overrated 6-hour pizza date and come here. Despite the fact that the sandwiches here are all priced $2 more than they probably should be, the ingredients are all fresh and the bread is high quality munching.

I stop by here fairly often and I've only had one or two iffy sandwiches, but nothing that ever stopped me from finishing them.

This place has the most delicious sandwiches! They're very reminiscent of the ones I've had in Italy -- simple, quality ingredients that all adds up to a delicious sandwich. Haven't had the other menu items yet, but I'm definitely dying to try them. I'd say go here for the sandwiches alone!

This place is very simple, take-out only, three kinds of regular sandwiches with another special market sandwich, several kinds of salads, a few types of Italian soda or alike, that's all! It's that simple and quick, yet always packed. 

My favorite is the mozzarella, tomato and basil sandwich. Freshly baked bread from the on-site brick oven with the home made mozzarella, fresh local tomato and basil, it's that simple and delicious!!! Trust me, $8 for a big and high-quality sandwich, you'll be very satisfied!

Only drawback is that it only opens for lunch, 11am-3pm, and only Tuesday - Saturday. Maybe that's why people keep going back!

Pane Bianco represents the gentrified hipsters paradise. This place just secretes the undeserved smug vibe. Besides the hipster crew, get ready to meet the world traveler who is yakking it up about his travels across the American Southwest and how he pities America right now... or the overwhelmed Scottsdale mom with the 2 bratty kids, but she's completely ignoring them. You certainly see a melody of personalities at Pane Bianco. 

While I certainly never judge a place by it's appearance or it's customer base (I love holes in the wall), there was just something about Pane Bianco that rubbed me the wrong way... and it got a little more interesting when I ordered my meal.

I ordered the Tuna sandwich, which comes with red onion, Gaeta olives, lemon and arugula. This all comes on what I believe is ciabatta bread, but I'm not sure. I asked the lady behind the counter if I could sub out the olives for the roasted peppers. Her answer was simply "No".... In my mind my first thought was "okay, maybe a place like this doesn't do substitutions", which I understood. She told me that they won't put the peppers on the tuna because it wouldn't work with the sandwich. I was shocked... so I asked her nicely to please ask someone if they could do it. After waiting around for awhile, I went to pay for my meal. As my sandwich was being wrapped, she said yes they could do it, but for some large fee (I believe 2.50 or 3 dollars, remind you this is an 8 dollar sandwich). By this time I was pretty worn out of the whole experience of Pane Bianco that I just said no thanks and went to eat my sandwich. Thanks, but a little too late.

Granted the sandwich was pretty good, and the tuna was very fresh. I just couldn't believe that someone would tell me that I couldn't get something on the menu put on my sandwich... for the reason that she didn't believe they went together. 

I spent much of my childhood in South Philadelphia living on homestyle Italian... and tuna and peppers definitely do go together...

In summary, I will try Pane Bianco again, and will most likely update my review based off of the service I receive. The sandwich was very good, and is the main reason I will go back. Hopefully I have a different experience.

With a sandwich, you have to have great bread...Chris Bianco is a master breadmaker. The fresh basil, tomato and buffalo mozzarella sandwich is to die for (not to mention everything else)! Worth every bite!

I think the food alone deserves five stars, but the limited menu keeps me at four.  4.5 would be more accurate.  I had a delicious mozzarella/tomato/basil sandwich.  It was great (not spectacular) mainly because of the bread. Arizona is seriously lacking in the bread dept., but Pane Bianco makes some of the best I've had here.    Gf had the market sandwich, which was lamb, I didn't like it as much as mine. I love being able to sit at the tables outside.  Parking was very easy.  I even enjoyed a delicious latte next door at Lux.  All-in-all, a very good experience.  I'll be back for sure.

Great lunchtime place as long as you know what to expect. Look at the menu before you go - see the menu photos here.

The menu is very simple and consistent. It doesn't change much. There are daily specials but that doesn't give a great variety to the menu.

What they do make is amazing! The bread is fresh, the meats and produce are tasty and simple. I've never had bad food here.

The table service side, opposite the take-out counter, serves the same menu. You just get the convenience of a waiter or waitress. When I've sat at a table the staff is fast and attentive and has great suggestions if you want them.

Tried chicken sandwich. Pizza. And mozzarella sandwich. One thing. Its not for the people who want a hearty lunch. But very hip and cute place for a lunch. Very health conscious. Not a burden for the ladies and gents who still want to eat out But not gain 10 lbs. Very flavorful.

Husband and I split a sandwich and a salad, carryout to the picnic tables outside.  .  Sopraseta sandwich: very nice.  Market salad (escarole, Gorgonzola, red onion and bread crumb): tasty, but overpriced at $11.  This was would be a nice side salad, not a lunch.  If you get table service, i believe bread comes with the salad, which would have made it more acceptable--the bread in the sandwich was wonderful.

Pros: cool atmosphere, good service, good location, quality ingredients

Cons: limited menu (3 salads, only 4 sandwiches at a place called bread), very frufru

More pros than cons on the list, but I didn't like my chicken salad sandwich even though the ingredients were of good quality. There wasn't much chicken but a lot of arugula and apples. I'm okay with some diced apple as a garnishment but there were so many that it overpowered the sandwich and made it too sweet. Not the savory taste I'm looking for with a chicken salad sandwich. Cool atmposhere, but not cool enough to go to and not be satisfied with the food.

Pane Bianco has, by far, the best caprese (mozzarella, tomato, and basil) sandwich that I've ever experienced.  The mozzarella is incredibly fresh and creamy, and the tomatoes are always super ripe and flavorful.  Last week I tried the caprese sandwich at Cafe Centro, who does have an amazing ham and swiss, and nearly got homesick for Pane Bianco =) If not for one mediocre experience with a pork sandwich I would give them 5 stars. Oh, and being next to Lux (http://www.yelp.com/biz/lux-coffeebar-phoenix) doesn't hurt one bit.  Great way to spend an afternoon!
One of my favorite places in town, yes !! Best pizza ever !! Customer service great!! Amazing staff !!!! Muy chingon
What in the world is Chef Chris doing to that tuna fish sandwich? You want the BEST tuna fish in the world?!?  GO TO P.B. try the buffalo mozzarella & tomato sandwich as well. Heaven on a plate!
I am extremely discriminating when it comes to food and these honestly might be the best sandwiches I've ever had.  You will not be disappointed - and if you were, you are a very sick person.

I visited and ordered carry out based on a friend's recommendation. It's a small place and has a neat appearance inside. The menu is written in chalk on a large board, and each table setting has a menu as well. 

They don't have noodles except on Fridays is what I was told. I ordered meatballs and a pizza pie to goad I really wanted to try their pasta because I'm a sucker for good pasta.   

The food was very good.

After six months of living only a block away from Pane, I was so excited to finally enjoy one of their lunchtime sandwiches! Like many other people, I had the Mozzarella, Tomato and Basil sandwich and was not disappointed. They didn't skimp on any of the ingredients, and I was especially pleased with the light salt-and-pepper seasoning on the tomatoes. Yum!

The service was very friendly and my date and I luckily ordered before the 15 people behind us did, so we only waited 10-15 minutes for our meal. The only thing I didn't like was paying for the bottle of water. I just wanted a cup of tap, I didn't need a bottle of Italian spring water or whatever it was. It won't stop me from going here again though - next time I'll just bring water from home.

Went w/ 4 adult friends (and a teen) for a birthday dinner a couple wks ago. Food was really very exceptional, loved the casual ambience (we sat in the separate alcove) and the service was really above and beyond. I usually do not give glowing restaurant critiques but this was a very special night mainly because of the aforementioned. I'm definitely going back. My only detraction was the cost---almost 300$ and yes, we did have wine but NOT excessive amounts. Just be careful with what you wish  for.......

Who cares what they put on it-that bread is amazing! It's fresh baked and chewy and delicious. The mozzarella sandwich is delicious too. Somehow the tomatoes are ripe and fresh year round. I love the little caramels they throw in with every order, as well. 

What I don't like is that it's a little pricey for what you get. I understand the complaints that there's nowhere to sit and very little beverage options, but it's set up to be a takeout place. It's a decent trade-off. 

I haven't ventured over to the pizza place yet, as I can't fathom any meal worth waiting over 3 hours for. The quality of this place, though, makes me believe that it's gotta be pretty tasty.
Pane Bianco- not what I expected. Disappointing & Unfriendly staff.  The sandwiches are alright, however there are no sides or chips. They should stick to pizza!

Loved the place. Wonderful fresh food. Bread is something I would come here again for!
The salad that came as side had yummy dressing and was well done. Great unique decor. One of those places that inspires me to be a restauranteur :).

I went back recently and noticed thatt the quantity of tuna they use in the sandwich has DRAMATICALLY decreased.  The bread is still as good as ever but it was a little disappointing to see that happen.  Hopefully it was just a once time thing.  Will keep you posted...

I really like this place. My mom loves this place. My girlfriend loves it too.

I'm knocking it a couple stars for the following reasons:

1. If I call in an order, I want it to be waiting for me so I can avoid standing in line with the rest of the mouth breathers. I'm a busy guy, I'm a mover and shaker, I've got shit going on, and standing for an hour in line waiting on a sandwich, which albeit is awesome, is just kind of a waste of my time. 

2. When I am not all on my A game to call things in, that place sucks on ice to stand around in. Its small, its warm, and a lot of hippie-dippy types tend to like to eat there. Its a free country, eat where you want, but do a brother a favor and take a shower. Quit making me believe the joke "Where's the best place to hide money from a hippie? Under the soap!"

3. I'm what you might call a "man with an 'eating disorder.'" Shortly put, so long as there isn't fish or chicken in it, I eat everything, and with much gusto I might add. Some sides might be nice. Don't get me wrong, the "wafer thin mint" is a nice touch, but maybe something else to go with my ultra healthy sandwich. 

I get it, I'm hard to please, but I don't think these are unreasonable requests. Maybe deodorant at the door if you have dreads? Just a though...

Came here for a Saturday lunch soon after moving to Phoenix. Our group of 5 found a seat easily and we enjoyed salads and sandwiches. I was happy with my chicken salad sandwich and thought the bread was great. My only complaint is I wish they were open on weeknights and at all on Sundays. I'd like to go back and try the pizza.

Hands down my favorite lunch spot in PHX.  Their focaccia is some of the best I've ever had, and I could eat the farm chicken sandwich every day of my life.  Great setting with out of this world food.  What the menu lacks in quantity, it more than makes up for in quality.  Pro tip: do not pass on the rice pudding, you'll thank me later.

I really enjoy their lunch and dinner. A little known secret is that they serve pizza after 4pm. The pizza is the reason that we first tried this place. Now that they have opened the option to sit inside, it is a great place to take out or eat in. I am a huge fan of their Marinara Pizza while my boyfriend swears by the Margherita. It's the same price you will pay at Pizzeria Bianco and basically the same quality, minus the Pizzeria Bianco atmosphere and wait. For lunch I have the Housemade Mozzarella, Local Tomato & Basil sandwich or salad. The Mozzarella is fresh and delicious and I do not normally eat cheese. One more thing, I love that I can buy a pizza here and go next door to Lux, order a lemonade and read a book while enjoying my pizza. Great place! The only caveat is that the wait at lunch time can be up to 20-25 mins during peak hours (downtown Phoenix lunch crowd).

I've heard this place is delicious and has clean food which I do enjoy. Eating healthy has now becoming a part of my lifestyle. I was told this place was a sister company of another restaurant. 
It's kinda hidden when we first pulled up next to a bicycle shop. They had a patio out front which was a nice option if you didn't want to eat inside. I didn't know what to expect before entering but when I entered the place, it seemed as if I was taken back in time. I was a little confused at what I've heard and the mental thought I already had, and the incorporation that was now in front of me. It was like an old, vintage, antique-ish, theme. (Maybe this shop is like those in Italy?) One side was to-go and other side was dine in with tables. It wasn't a busy lunch day but maybe half the tables were filled with people during this time. It was quiet, no music, and the sounds of your table neighbors.  I like this for the fact that you can actually talk and hear your lunch dates. The tables were already set with fork, knife, napkin, and menu. Presented a nice clean atmosphere.  They had a chalkboard up against the wall that noted the all the daily special, in this case lunch specials including meals and drinks. Our waitress was so kind to read and tell us the daily special. Looking through the menu, it wasn't so detailed with descriptions of what was inside each sandwhich or salad. Since it was a new place for me to try, I was all game for what the surprise would be. They had their sandwhich and salads and veggie soup in the front and drinks in the back. I heard their sandwhiches are pretty scrumptious but I was in the mood for eating like a rabbit, so I opted for a salad. I ended up getting the 2 wash ranch salad I believe is the name? As far as my date, he had the special pulled beef sandwhich and their square pieces of appetizer pizza.
To my surprise my salad was loaded. It came with a piece of bread wrapped in brown paper that reminded me that you would wrap fish if you were to get from a market. The salad had lots of dark mixed greens which had already been tossed in their dressing (delicious, but i cant figure out exactly what is in it!) and they had sliced one fresh tomato in half (which still had the vines on it) and a scoop of what looked like their version of chicken salad. Inside their chicken salad was tiny chops of chicken with red onion, celery, quinoa, and possibly minced parsely or basil? It was very delicous, light, refreshing, and made my tummy full and satisfied. Also, food came out quick. I think after ordering, it literally might have came out 7 min later. That was quite impressing. I would def recommend for people to try and I am definitely coming back for seconds another day, next time I'll try their sandwhiches.

I dont want to love this place because it is expensive, but it is really hard to get that moz sandwich out of my mind!!  Fresh bread, perfect combo of ingredients, its terrific. i also like to try the market sandwich, and it doesn't disappoint. These sandwiches are big enough to share, especially if you get drinks from LUX next door too.

Mozzarella sandwich or the market sandwich of the day are go-tos. Usually have a good selection of beer and wine, too.

Before it gets hot, definitely sit outside on the covered patio-- the interior is a cross between hipster and Anthropologie catalog.

Upfront:  It is take out only.  They are only open for lunch, Monday through Saturday.  If it isn't too hot, there are tables outside you can enjoy lunch at.  You place your order, stand off to the side.  Someone will call your name, and you pay.  Then you stand off to the side again.  A little while later you'll receive your food.  Be patient.

I have yet to find friends interested in waiting for Pizzeria Bianco, so I've gotten my Bianco curiosity fix here.  9.5 times out of 10 I have ordered the basil, tomato and mozzerlla sandwich.  It is that good.  It is also (for me) large enough to have half for lunch and half as an afternoon snack around 3:30 pm.

I have tried the tuna salad.  It was good but the basil, tomato, mozzerella sandwich is just SO good, that I've never gotten the salad a second time.  They have a daily salad and sandwich special that is always changing.  A few times I have gotten the sandwich special when it involves prosciutto...also delicious.

This place is so good.  Highly recommend for out of towners who have heard of the magical ways of Chris Bianco but don't want/can't wait the several hours to eat at Pizzaria Bianco.

Decent place, stopped by for dinner for a friends birthday.  

Food was good, but the real winner here is the service!

As you walk in, the aroma of freshly baked bread gets you. We had the Tuna Sandwich, and the salad version of it. Not THAT good, but just right.
 The wait can be up to 15 minutes though...apparently they kid you not when they say everything is made FRESH.

You know I've been eating Chris's pizza for about ten years now and the pizza I had today was just as great as the first one I had years ago.  However, if the little princess working the counter doesn't give a shit if I am there or not and the best she can do is hand me my pizza and the wrong salad with a "here you go," I can just as easily drive through federal pizza a few blocks north where the people who work there couldn't be any nicer.

I was in Phoenix for a day and found this place for lunch using Yelp. I must say that I really liked it. The place has a very laid back feel and has a very rustic and antiquated atmosphere. 

When we sat down, we were served immediately. Our server was really good. He was enthusiastic and was knowledgable about the menu. 

What we got: 
*Mozzarella Sandwich: This was really good. Fresh mozzarella served with tomato and fresh basil on split foccacia sandwiches and dressed lightly with olive oil. Extremely fresh, refreshing and light.

*Chicken Salad: Fresh, juicy chicken and the dressing was refreshing. 

One small gripe: Cutlery was placed on the left instead of the right. 

Definitely will be back if I'm in the area!

Had really bad service that one time, but it's been great ever since. 
Bread has improved. (Maybe I got a bad loaf considering I normally love it?) Love the fresh local approach and fresh milled flours used.

Some people celebrate with champagne or a white girl scream on the dance floor; I do it with a sandwich.  When I'm having a bad day, or a great day or it's just a beautiful day, I go to Pane Bianco and devour the entire tomato/basil/mozzarella sandwich .  I do this alone because it' s slightly embarrassing to literally moan while eating.  

Yeah, that's right.  I call it "The Sandwich that Makes me Moan".   

And then I eat the caramel.  All of it.  

And then I neatly fold up the smart brown bag like my little badge of honor and stash it away with the others. It's no coincidence that any gift I give seems to fit perfectly in that bag.  Cover the stamp with a fun pic and voila- a gift is born.  

Chris Bianco, you're a damn genius.  You know exactly what you're doing and do it well.

i have been a fan of chris bianco, both professionally and personally since the late 80s when he first made his pizzas at euromarket, now AJ's on central and camelback. this is his outlet for sandwiches, though with the recent addition of his personalble brother marco, and hardworking robbie, it has expanded to evenings and other  entrees as well. in october, the james beard award winning pizza will also be available in this outlet as well as downtown. but i go for the sandwiches, ranging from fritattas,to ham, turkey, procuisutto, meatball, lamb, jarmon. sausage, and more. the roasted red peppers, and tomatoes are to die for as they are assembled on freshly baked bread that you see being baked right before your eyes. the prices have recently gone up, probably to pay for the expansion. the italian ices served during the summer are the ideal desset. they have sodas available, made with cane sugar only. no corn syrup. a loaf of bread is only 3 bux. but the sandwiches can be pricey...up to 12 dollars for the daily market special. my roommate swears by the tuna, made with lemon juice and olives. this is not your grandmother's tuna...it is imported from portugal and is delicious. i have a friend, tony , who lives crosstown and will travel here just to satisfy his crave for this particular sandwich. lines can be lengthy, so it could take 15 minutes during lunch rush hour, but nothing like the waits downtown. there are outdoor tables, and each bag is garnished with a piece of candy for dessert. fans of susan pool will be disappointed she is no longer with the staff. and speaking of the staff, many of them have been working at pane bianco since it started, all are friendly and knowledgeable. just about everything in your sandwich was grown or cultivated in arizona, and freshness is apparent..whether its a sandwich or a melon salad.  is this place for everyone? probably not. but if you have standards of criticism when it comes to food, you should be pleased with the effort made, and result on your taste buds.

Ok, I have to say that the tomato basil sandwich at this place is unbelievably charismatic and delicious......and I love me some sandwiches......this one is definately one of my favorites. From the first bite to the last I am in love with this sandwich.....slightly weird I know. The bread is fresh baked wood fired........um awesome. The tomatoes are fresh and I am pretty sure, locally grown.....so they are full of flavor and then there is the mozarella......oh sweet mother of god....sooooo good. My mom and I usually go about twice a week and split one and I look forward to it every time.

I used to be a huge huge fan of this place.  But, recently they seem to have quality control issues.  One issue has been the bread---which used to be nothing short of awesome.  One a couple of recent visits (off the lunch time rush) the bread tasted like it had been sitting around (in one case, the sandwich was inedible).  A second issue has been seasoning, which used to be perfect.  In one case, the sandwich lacked any taste and in another case, the moz was unevenly salted.  All of these are "sins" that are excusable from an ordinary sandwich shop with ordinary prices.  (Well, the inedible sandwich isn't excusable...)  But, I expect much better from PB.

~Pizza @ Pane Bianco~ 

  I am Hesitant, do I write this review or not?!
  I mean if I do not... I could plead the intoxication of FEZ's Fabulous sugar-rimmed WatermelonMargaritas (which come with genuine GummiWorms to "Lure" You).
 
  The 23rd of September was one of those RollerCoaster rides with My Mate.  At first He's, "I just want a small salad, I am kind of still full from lunch."  To, having the FullOn yummy monthly DinnerSpecial at FEZ, ~Crispy Chicken Cordon Bleu~ it came with a side of perfectly cooked spinach (which I did get a taste of).  We arrived at HappyHour and the WatermelonMargaritas were 2-4-1, so of course...

  Next, We headed North toward the next LightRail station, yet not before heading to LUX, where We realized We were not prepared to wait... They were a bit busy. 
  I suggested We pop into Pane Bianco for a loaf of bread from, Their wood burning oven.  We didn't even make it through the (new) front door before, the aroma of pizza hit Us.   After drinking like a fish and nibblin' on GummiWorms, I was so ready for pizza. 
  They only offer 4 different types of pizza from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m.;

MARGHERITA - Tomato Sauce, Fresh MozzarellaCheese, Basil
MARINARA - Tomato Sauce, Oregano, Garlic without Cheese
ROSA - Red Onion, ParmesanCheese, Rosemary, AZ Pistachios
BIANCOVERDE - Fresh MozzarellaCheese, ParmesanCheese, RicottaCheese, Arugula 

  You would think it would not be a  difficult choice, think again.  I finally narrowed it down to the Rosa only to be told by the sweet, petite, CounterGirl that the Bakers were still getting Their game on, so I could have a second pizza for free. 
  TooMuch for My alcohol infused GreyMatter to process, Mate tells Her to make the second one a Margherita.

  Okay so here's My Dilemma, do I even try to tell You how IndescribablyGood, a pizza with ArizonaGrown pistachios is/can be. That a wood burning oven cooks a pizza in less than 10 minutes, so We were in and out in less than 20 minutes. That soon Pane Bianco will be attempting another form of seduction by serving, Crow's Dairy Gelato.

Maybe...
  You are not someone who reads My reviews, someone who does not understand the subtleties of Flavour, someone who does not love Locally Grown. 
Maybe, Maybe not. 

Do I risk it?!?!

These are simply the BEST sandwiches and salads. If you like your food (a) locally grown; (b) freshly made; (c) organic/all natural; and (d) yummy - and who doesn't? - this is the place for you.

Now, admittedly they have something of a soup-nazi routine set up and if you walk in and don't know the drill, it can be confusing.  So pay attention:   
1.  Look at menu.
2.  Decide what you want.
3.  Wait your turn to order.
4.  Order (give your name).
5.  Wait your turn to be called to pay the other girl for the order you placed.
6.  Pay her.
7.  Wait until your food is ready.
8.  Leave with your food.

Note that there is no place to sit inside - so you can either sit outside, or, (if it is 157 degrees out that day), see if you can find a place to sit over at LUX, they are very welcoming of Pane Bianco diners. 

It's all good.

There is no better vegetarian Sandwhich in the valley. The Fresh mozzarella, tomatoes and basil is unreal. I love meat and could eat this all the time. Pizzas are pure Bianco style and hot and crispy every time. Look out for great specials. A regular spot for my family.

I was visiting a friend in Phoenix and she recommended Pane Bianco. In short (which is appropriate because this place has few things on the menu, but does them all well), Love it.  The outdoor seating is totally fitting for the atmosphere, the bread is delicious and rustic and the panini are really delicious. The coffee shop is still urban but less utilitarian than Pane.  The sandwiches and salads are very reasonably priced IMO.

This place is amazing! I had such a great experience. This was my first time here and I loved it. Some of the best mozzarella I have ever had, and the desert was fantastic, I don't really know what it was called but it was like an apple caramel cake thing and it was so good. The service was fantastic the people who work here are just super friendly and were very welcoming. I will most definitely be coming back!

Saturday night, rolled in around 9 pm. No wait, and plenty of bench space on the patio. It was a nice night, so we ate outdoors. 

Pizzas here do not have meat toppings, unlike at the original pizzeria bianco. did not know that. :( We ordered the meat appetizer to compensate.

Pizzas came out hot (we ordered all minus the marinara), and in to go boxes. The crust was very crispy on the edges, but floppy towards the middle. excellent quality toppings. Meat appetizer was a mix of chicken (simmered in italian spices), sausage, and cured meat wrapped around cheese on a stick.  It was very good as well.

Only one gripe: it was so dark outside that you couldn't see the food that you were eating. Part of the joy of food is enjoying the beauty of it, hence food porn! I wish they would put up some xmas lights or other overhead lighting - it would create some ambiance!

**Takeout review**

I've tried the other bianco businesses in town and I am a big fan.

I couldn't resist the margherita pizza with the market salad.

The salad was a shredded Brussels sprout slaw with cabbage, radishes, grapes, and the highlight: an amazing blue cheese that literally was the star of the meal.

My pizza was fresh with nice simple preparation of a classic red sauce spotted with mozzarella and basil.  Unfortunately for me this was about soggy in the center but I warmed my pizza stone at home to crisp it up. 

As far as the service, Ariel was professional and kind when I picked up my order.  She took the time to ask about my day and invited me back soon.  Next time I will dine in because the wine selection looks great.

The look and taste of organic food without any of the philosophy behind it....and the bread is very difficult to sink your teeth into.

I know...I know...I just berated your favorite sandwich shop. But really, this is your favorite place because either (1) your options are so limited in the area or (2) you require a feeling of prestige to eat.

It's good to be organic. The ingredients taste delicious. I don't even mind paying $10 for a vegetarian sandwich that tastes good (albeit difficult to eat) and a water for lunch. But what bothers me is the mixed message that's more like false advertizing. 

First there is no place to sit inside at all. So chances are, you're getting this meal to-go (with all the packaging that entails). There's outdoor seating that is shared with Cafe Lux (fair trade cafe that's awesome but similarly expensive). Seating is not available at typical eating times and lines may be long.

Second, you cannot order a beverage from the US, Mexico or anywhere that it might arrive in even a remotely sustainable way. All their drinks are from Italy. There's no option for fountain drinks or even local bottled water. If you ask for a drink that hasn't traveled 5,000 miles to be here, they point you to a water cooler  in the cafe next door.

Third, the service sucks. There are plenty of people working there, almost tripping over each other politely trying to not infringe of anyone's  space  by trying to use the cash register.

Fourth,  The decoration is designed to make you feel like it's sustainable from recycled organic materials. They even offer an organic tote bag for sale ($10).  This is their attempt to offer a solution for all the waste created by the perpetual to-go-ness. It's almost like they're laughing at you calling you an "idiot".  We can call this 'the bleeding heart tax'. If you forgot your recycled to-go bag at home, they can give you another one for the price of two meals.

Fifth and finally, the bread is hard to eat. So you can't take a bite of your sandwich without it falling apart a bit. There are no silverware to save you from the embarrassment of using your hands. The wrapping is brown paper with very thick wax paper lining, so you can't use it to wrap around your sandwich to keep it together while you're trying to tear pieces of the bread off with your teeth.

But they give you a sweet with every order....and if you decide to come back with your empty glass bottle from Italy, they will recycle it for you.  --And if you start coming here regularly you will look very hip when the people who work there remember your name, order and the fact that you do not require a boutique to-go bag.

I'd eat from there again, if you pick up the order and return the empty Italian bottles for me.

So let me tell you, my favorite food is sandwiches, and I have eaten a TON of them.  This place just didn't do it for me.

I went there after I'd heard a few of my customers raving about it, so I thought Id try it out.

1.  No parking
2.  Waited in a long line
3. Asked for a recommendation from the cashier since I'd never been there and she just said I should "pick something"
4. Waited 15 minutes in a crowded room with weird people.
5.  Took my sandwich outside and sat at a table, first bite was dryer than sandpaper.  (The bacon was good though)
6.  After 2 bites my sandwich was instantly cold making the bread as thick as a sweater.  
7.  Threw half of it away and was pissed because i paid so much.
8.  Two stars for the good chocolate bar.
Been here several times over the last year.  I don't mind the price knowing that I'm getting quality food and ingredients.  The bread is delicious and atmosphere is unique!  We will return!
The mozzarella tomato and basil sandwich is the BEST sandwich in Phoenix, hands down. If you haven't been to Pane Bianco you are truly missing out.

3.5 stars..Wanted to love this place and do really like it. Thought the menu was limited but very fresh. The market sandwich was a winner. Didn't care for the tuna at all. The balsamic made it far too sweet for this tuna fan. The pickled sides were a highlight. The lentil soup was good, not great. 
Love the decor of the place, especially the mid century modern swag lighting over the bar. It is an eclectic casual joint but a bit pricey. We will return and give it another whirl.

I drove up and I parked in the insanely full parking lot.

I walk in to Pane Bianco and I am the only one there?  Apparently LUX is the most popular place in all of Phoenix, and the owners of these two businesses are affiliated with one another...

So...let's just say the service when you are the only diners there was impeccable.  Oh, I ordered my sandwich. I said a sentence. And then my sandwich (plus a small slaw/salad that came with, gratis) arrived.  INSANELY fast.

I guzzle water like I'm dying of thirst, and I never even had to look for our server to refill the glass.  She was there to help out but not obtrusively so.

Dined in and took my excess half of the tomato, basil and (housemade!) mozzerella sandwich home for dinner! Not bad to get two full meals for a $10 sandwich!
The perfect sandwich for national sandwich day! Love the package of the take out sandwiches. The bread is delicious and I just love the sandwich. I will definitely come back soon!

I'm a big fan of Chris Bianco's food and this place is really good!

I had a soup and a sandwich and left pretty pleased with a full belly, a smile in my face and my wallet didn't suffer.

I will have to go back to try more items of the menu!

Cheers.

I really enjoyed this place. The atmosphere was great and so was the food. The seating was family style outside at picnic tables (only in Phoenix). You order your food, get it in a brown paper bag, and head outside to enjoy the balmy Phoenix winter. The bread is made in-house in a flat brick wood-burning oven. I had the homemade mozzarella, basil, and local tomato sandwich on flat bread. That was some of the smoothest, most flavorful mozzarella I've ever had. Thanks to the yelp reviews, I knew that was what I was getting as soon as I walked in. Also check out the cold case for locally made treats. I had some vanilla bean rice pudding that rocked my world. Hit up Lux next door for some really tasty espresso after the sammy and you've got yourself one hell of a good lunch.

I take everyone here - this place is amazing.

Sandwiches are a little expensive but they are all SOOO good and come with a free candy (love the carmels!).

Favorite sando is the Tomato, Basil, Mozzerella and 2nd favorite is the Sopresatta.  

I LOOOOOOOOOOOOVE Pane Bianco!

The pizza absolutely lived up to the hype here - incredibly tasty and hot out of the oven. Definitely go for the fennel & sausage pizza... that was a total winner. The meatballs were a hidden gem as well - the sauce was fantastic and the whole dish tasted like home.

I'm surprised I haven't reviewed Pane! I've been coming here for years. I've only eaten lunch here once and had the caprese sandwich (divine). But dinner! Dinner here is where it's at! 

Pane Bianco has the freshest ingredients for great prices. They serve the same six pizzas that you can find at their Pizzeria locations (without the hour+ wait times to get a table) for the same price ($12-16)! If you don't try the Rosa, with its perfect blend of red onion and pistachios, you are missing out. It's honestly the best pizza I've ever had in my ENTIRE LIFE(!!!) The margherita is also blissfully on point. They have seasonal dinner specials and I was really happy with a pear salad our server recommended. Did I mention their service? It's some of the best I've experienced. The servers know the food and are always quick to suggest something new.

They have a bar section, a few small tables and plenty of communal-style table seating. The lighting is perfect, and you can always pop in next door to their take out section, order a pizza or a loaf of their fresh-baked bread and walk over to Lux for a latte. There is plenty of outside seating that they share with Lux, but I'm not too sure if they will serve you outside (definitely not if you're planning on having a glass of wine). 

Pane Bianco is a true gem of the downtown/uptown Phoenix area.

We've been here 4-5 times and enjoy the low-key environment, open space and friendly service.  Last night was no exception.  We arrived at 7pm or so on a Friday night and were seated immediately just inside the door at a funky blue table for two that old carvings in it.  The servers worked together to make sure that we had beverages ( Pinot Noir and a Sangiovese) and inform us of the evenings specials.  

We ordered the Lasagna, the Mozzarella, Tomato & Basil Salad (The Best in Town), and the special Antipasto Platter that included grilled asparagus, sweet potatoes, beets, cauliflower and garlic cloves.  The only hiccup for the pleasant dinner was that the three servings took over 25 minutes to come out.  We had a few slices of their excellent bread to satiate us, but the salad was the last item to come from the kitchen and we had asked the food to come as soon as it was ready.  

In closing, the management was kind enough to comp a few things for the wait.  We will return again soon!

This was one of those days where I was out and a bout and decided to stop in and see what this place was all about.  I have been following them on instagram for months.  Today they were featuring their version of the blt.  Some how they figured out how to transform the classic sandwich into the best blt I've ever ate.  The bread and bacon where the stars of this one with the garlic spread and heirloom tomatoes as the co-stars. This place is a winner!

Food Guy Out!
Very delicious tomato basil mozzarella sandwich. A bit over-priced but you deserve to spoil yourself every once in a while.

Excellent place for food. I've only been here twice but the food is so tasty. I really love the atmosphere of it, especially on a Saturday or Sunday brunch time. 4 out of 5 simply because they're NEVER OPEN!
Chris Bianco's sandwiches are like breast milk for grown-ups.
The sandwich was good but I paid $14 dollars for it and that's the only thing it came with. Who charges $14 for a sandwich? Can't believe I actually paid for it. But won't go back again.

Fresh + Simple = Delicious

This was my first outing to Pane Bianco. I have been to the pizzeria and it was great. So I have been trying to make my way to Pane Bianco for a few months. On a whim I decided to stop by for lunch. I totally forgot they are only open a few hours and made it in a few minutes after 2pm. 

Upon my arrival it was packed inside. However, the staff is very observant. They greeted me promptly and motioned for me to come place my order as so not to get caught up with the people that were waiting for their food. I place my order mozzarella, tomato and basil sandwich. The market sandwich of the day sounded really good, lamb and arugula. But it was already sold out. Ohh well maybe next time. 

As I waited for my food with my stomach beating a hole in my back I noticed how neat the place was. Also how organized the system was. I have to say I did wait about 30 mins for my food. But the smart folks called their orders in. If you know you are going there I would highly suggest doing this. It could be a time saver. Now I know. 

My name is finally called and I am happy as a pig in crap. I make my way over to one of the tables outside to partake in this wonderful creation. My sandwich looks like a perfect slice of heaven. The basil, oil and pepper tickle my nose as I get ready to take a bite. It is so great to anticipate something and for your expectations to be met. The bread was crusty, the basil so very fresh, the tomato just right and the CHEESE. OMG this is the best mozzarella cheese I have ever had. As I ate my sandwich and drinking their version of Sprite, which by the way was one of the best sodas I ever had. I dropped a piece of my cheese on the table. What to do? Eat it or not. Ohh dilemmas...I did not eat it but I felt awful that this piece was lost to the gross factor.  But my spirits rose again when I saw I  had a little piece of chocolate waiting for me at the end of my meal. Whoa baby...now you really have made my day.

After I ate at the pizzeria a few months ago. I refused to eat pizza anywhere else for quite some time. Every time I thought of pizza I remembered what I had at Bianco's. So I am guessing the same will happen with sandwiches. It is hard to go back to mediocre or even good after you have one of these sandwiches. 

Do yourself a favor, call in your order if you want something of the regular menu or you can relax and enjoy the ambiance, knowing that your slice of heaven is being prepared for you while you wait.

Always go for the tomato basil mozzarella sandwich on fresh baked bread. So glad the hours are expanded. Parking is always a bit difficult so best to go during none meal hours.   With the nicer weather it also means there is a chance to get outside tables when it is less crowded.   Family style seating inside so be prepared to share other than just a couple of small tables.
Super cute spot with the freshest of the fresh ingredients. Tasty sandwiches and salads. Fast and friendly service. Adorable country farm feel. What's not to love?
Such a nice feeling and great lunch fresh unique approach.  Some nice artwork to enjoy while sipping local brews or wine

This place is divine. I love the food, vibe, everything about it. I think it's even better than Pizzeria Bianco because I'm more of a sandwich person and only having a 10 minute wait doesn't hurt either. My idea of a perfect lunch is coming here on a nice day, getting a caprese sandwich, eating outside on the picnic benches, and finishing with a caramel that comes with the sandwich. 

The bread is charred and smoky. Mozzarella is perfect. Basil and tomato,so fresh, it pops. Every flavor is just intensified because of the quality of the ingredients. Simple, but perfect. I have also tried the tuna. Good, but now wow. And the soppressata is too salty for my tastes. 

This is truly gourmet in a unassuming environment. Must try for anybody in the Phoenix area.

Wow, great fresh food!
tomato mozzarella sandwich was terrific.  Fresh house made Mozzarella and real tomato flavor.
Everyone in our party had something different, all very good.

I think I have a new addiction.  The mozzerella-tomato-basil sandwich from Pane Bianco.  Paired with one of those all-natural colas, it was pretty much perfect.

It would have been completely perfect if I had been able to sit on a patio (away from Central) to enjoy my simple and delicious sandwich in the lovely sunshine.

4.5 stars.

I've heard so many great things about this place so I decided to try it because I was in town. I got the sopressata sandwich which came with a tasty vinegar slaw with apples. I do wish the sandwich was as toasted which may be an option that I didn't know about. But the sandwich was great and I love that they make their own bread in house! The place is pretty small but had a really cute feel.
Great bread and homemade mozzarella to go. Sandwiches very nice, large enough to share if you're not too hungry.

If I had three words to describe my meal here it would be.....drum roll please......Simple......Is.......King!!!  I finally decided to check this place out (how can I call myself a foodie when this place has been a 2 minute drive from my house for a few years, and I've never been?) for lunch today. I ordered the Sopressata, Aged Provolone and Roasted Peppers. That was literally the entire sandwich, except of course the bread (which was more of an awesome baked pizza crust) What a killer sandwich!! I did shell out 9 bones for a sandwich with no side, but man this place is great. Most of the time, I'm a quality over quantity guy so no biggie. I dig the straight forward "we are open for fours hours a day, don't have any tables, there's 4 sammies and two salads on the menu,, what biatch" attitude they have. I guess when you do it right, you can do what ever  you want. Nanny nanny boo boo all you oversized glutounous sandwich shacks, PB is the bizniss!!!

I love love love this place! The tmb sandwich is the best around. Everything from the bread, to the cheese to the veggies are fresh and flavorful. A definite must try if you're downtown. But don't expect there to be much seating though. It's pretty much a to go kinda place. There's a few benches outside, but it's pretty much take and go. So just a little heads up. They even have a few salads there, the caprese is the best. Try it, it's good and a definite repeat kind of place.

These sandwiches are so good, I would be willing to sit outside on those 115-degree days Phoenix supposedly gets, if that was the only way I could enjoy them. Combine it with Cowboy Ciao in Scottsdale and Cafe Elote in Sedona, and we pretty much had the perfect AZ food trifecta.

Bonus points for meeting Chris Bianco behind the counter. Yeah, I guess this place is named after him.

Server was very inattentive and didn't offer any "can I get you anything? How is everything? Would you like desert?" Salad was made wrong to order and the server saw we didn't eat other than one bite then took the plates away saying nothing. Extremely overpriced.

I have to copy Stephanie B's review below.  It's worth reading again.   It needs to be posted again for the sake of those unknowing customers who think they're getting something good out of this.
I don't know Stephanie B but what she said is dead on.  I couldn't agree more.  I think this place is overrated....and the bread is very hard to sink your teeth into.

I ordered 3 sandwiches - the regular tomato/mozzarella/basil, the proscuitto/cheese and the tuna.  Out of all 3, all priced at $8 each, the tomato/mozzarella/basil was the best.  But for you, reader, don't even waste your $8.  Just go to another place for good eats.  
Thank goodness I brought my own water in a stainless steel waterbottle.

Stephanie B's review:

"The look and taste of organic food without any of the philosophy behind it....and the bread is very difficult to sink your teeth into.

I know...I know...I just berated your favorite sandwich shop. But really, this is your favorite place because either (1) your options are so limited in the area or (2) you require a feeling of prestige to eat.

It's good to be organic. The ingredients taste delicious. I don't even mind paying $10 for a vegetarian sandwich that tastes good (albeit difficult to eat) and a water for lunch. But what bothers me is the mixed message that's more like false advertizing. 

First there is no place to sit inside at all. So chances are, you're getting this meal to-go (with all the packaging that entails). There's outdoor seating that is shared with Cafe Lux (fair trade cafe that's awesome but similarly expensive). Seating is not available at typical eating times and lines may be long.

Second, you cannot order a beverage from the US, Mexico or anywhere that it might arrive in even a remotely sustainable way. All their drinks are from Italy. There's no option for fountain drinks or even local bottled water. If you ask for a drink that hasn't traveled 5,000 miles to be here, they point you to a water cooler  in the cafe next door.

Third, the service sucks. There are plenty of people working there, almost tripping over each other politely trying to not infringe of anyone's  space  by trying to use the cash register.

Fourth,  The decoration is designed to make you feel like it's sustainable from recycled organic materials. They even offer an organic tote bag for sale ($10).  This is their attempt to offer a solution for all the waste created by the perpetual to-go-ness. It's almost like they're laughing at you calling you an "idiot".  We can call this 'the bleeding heart tax'. If you forgot your recycled to-go bag at home, they can give you another one for the price of two meals.

Fifth and finally, the bread is hard to eat. So you can't take a bite of your sandwich without it falling apart a bit. There are no silverware to save you from the embarrassment of using your hands. The wrapping is brown paper with very thick wax paper lining, so you can't use it to wrap around your sandwich to keep it together while you're trying to tear pieces of the bread off with your teeth.

But they give you a sweet with every order....and if you decide to come back with your empty glass bottle from Italy, they will recycle it for you.  --And if you start coming here regularly you will look very hip when the people who work there remember your name, order and the fact that you do not require a boutique to-go bag.

I'd eat from there again, if you pick up the order and return the empty Italian bottles for me."
The Housemade Mozzarella, Local Tomato & Basil sandwich is as good as it gets in the sandwich world.

Great sandwiches but a bit pricey.  Still definitely worth it.

PROS:
-- AC and I had prosciutto, tomato, mozzarella, and basil sandwiches and each individual ingredient was extremely tasty and fresh and melded together beautifully.
-- The bread was excellent - nice and chewy.
-- The basil in the sandwich was the best basil I've ever had.  I've grown basil at home myself and never had anything with such bright flavors.

CONS:
-- Very limited outdoor seating so you may be stuck eating outside in the blazing sun (or cold) or forced to take your food with you.
-- $8-10 for a takeout sandwich means this isn't really a good budget option.

Cute hipster spot for sandwiches with just little bistro seating in the shop and group seating outside.  The staff mentioned they were going to be opening a full service restaurant next door.

My friend and I got different sandwiches (salami and vegetarian) and they were very good.  The bread is freshly made at the shop and you can see them pull them out of the oven.

I liked it a lot and thought the vegetable soup was good (more of a stew really).

I had heard great things about Pizzeria Bianco and had been to LUX (the coffee shop next door), so I was excited at the chance to get to try this place.

They were out of the the market sandwich of the day, so we decided to go with the Caprese Sandwich.  Let me say this, never in AZ have I ever tasted anything close to what I experienced in Italy, until I came here.  The bread was the perfect combination of chewy and crunchy.  The tomatoes tasted like they came right off of the vine. The ultimate winner however, was the mozzarella.  So incredibly fresh! Slightly salty, perfect texture; literally heaven.  

I have not been there since they opened the Dine-in section, but plan on going back as soon as possible!
Some of the best Italian sandwiches I've had anywhere.  A simple place with wooden tables outside.  A hipster cafe spot next door.  Definitely worth it.
solid good food, little on the pricey end for what it is

Every Saturday for the last three weeks I've schlepped into Pane Bianco to get my fix. Though I feel tragically uncool in my saturday afternoon "best"(which may as well be pajamas) I bravely step up to the counter, say hello to the nice girls and order my delicious sandwich. And they are ALL delicious. The bread is truly orgasmic. They could hand out slices of the bread with nothing in between and I would still pay $9 to eat that shit. 
I'm intrigued by the alleged variety of the market sandwich. The tend to serve the same thing on the weekends, maybe I should try during the week sometime?

When I came here I had a flashback and thought I was back in Italy. Pane Bianco does only a few things but it does them right. I came here for lunch on hot day and ordered the mozzarella, tomato, basil sandwhich on their homemade foccacia and a vegetable soup with parmigianno. With the temperature as it was, the soup was a mistake, albeit a delicious one.

The sandwich was incredible. The bread was fresh and full of flavor, the mozzarella was creamy, and the basil added a nice crunch. Not to mention, they do not short change you on the portions; it was a massive sandwich.

They had salads as well and the place is great for takeout or eat-in.

As if the place wasn't awesome enough, it's right next to Lux, which is the coolest coffee shop I've ever been to. So grab a sandwich and an espresso and feel like you're in Italy for 10 minutes. Or at least until you realize it's 115 degrees.

Pane Bianco holds a special place in my food-heart. Maybe because I only ever eat here with the special-est of people, but I always feel transported when I walk through the doors to dine in. I absolutely love all the food, I adore the giant green olives that come with my sandwich, the bread as always is fantastic, and the staff is excellent. I don't go often because I would WANT to go every day & then I would be a huge fatty...so I save the beauty and delicious simplicity that is Pane for special days.
This place keeps it simple.  Only a few things on the menu, but it's all delicious!  Right next to lux, so you can get an iced chai with your tomato/mozzarella sandwich.  Yum!!!

Pane Bianco doubles as a fantastic bakery and restaurant. The menu items are made with the freshest of ingredients and delicious. The price is moderately high for lunch but definitely worth it. The decor and interior work wonderfully together to give you a very pleasurable dining experience. The most unique part of the interior is the bar which I was told was salvaged and was formerly an alter. Staff is friendly and knowledgable about the menu, ingredients, and specials.

A little known secret is that Pane Bianco is owned and operated by the same family who owns Pizzeria Bianco and you can get the same exact pizzas here even though they are not listed in the menu. All the same great taste, without any of the downtown wait for a table.

A must try location for anyone in the uptown area.

I'd been to the pizzeria the day before, and passing back through town again the next day, decided to give this place a try. I'm glad I did, because while my plan was to get another pizza, this time being able to sit outside with the dog and eat it, I ended up trying a special they had instead -- shepherds pie with lamb -- and it was really excellent. The lamb was cooked perfectly and there was plenty of it, and the potatoes, onions, etc. were flavorful. Very satisfying and filling on a chilly evening.

Had dinner on Valentine's and just amazing. Been a few times already but I think this was the best by far. Our server Annette was amazing and the food right on par. I hope the keep the Asparagus Market Salad, it was so good. Everything was great, right down to the scrumptious flourless chocolate cake!!!

I loved this place!  Went tonight for dinner and wine and had a great Panzanella!... I would definitely recommend it!  Ariel was super sweet and her service was outstanding.  Low sodium and perfectly balanced...,introducing cucumbers to it add a refreshing, crunching touch!  Glad you sliced them super thin and cut them in half. 
Decor, ambiance and quietness was perfect!  I love places where I can either talk to my friends without having to yell or be able to "have a conversation with myself" and still hear myself.

Welp, if you love Pizzeria Bianco (which anyone with half a taste bud should) then HEY! You've come to a similarly-named place!

All joking aside, let's talk about what makes anything Bianco great. It's a no-fuss menu with simple, homegrown ingredients in each dish. Nothing is complicated. It's fresh, it's delicious, and it's everything you want in a pizza or a sandwich.

Pane stands up to this testament. When I first went here with my boyfriend because he was adamant about having a sandwich and exclaimed this was the best sandwich in town, I have to admit I was neither impressed nor enthusiastic about the selection of sammies. I was like, "why does each sandwich only have, like, three ingredients including the bread?" I wanted some mayo-lined, cheese-filled meat tower with a pillowy outer layer of white bread.

What an idiot. Why does each sandwich only have 3 ingredients including the bread? Because that's all they need! My sandwich had roasted red peppers (roasted in-house) and some kind of salame; I think sopressata but I can't remember for sure. Oh, and bread. Fresh-baked bread. Made that morning. It was heaven in my mouth.

So if you know what's good for you, you will go to Pane and order a flippin' sandwich. Don't get your hopes up for mayo, you won't get. But you also won't want it or need it once have a single bite. My boyfriend was right (I HATE it when he's right!) This is the best sandwich in town.

As someone who literally went to Lux 5-6 times/week, it's no surprise that I sing such a song of praise for its next door neighbor Pane Bianco. Chris Bianco is a bread-making fiend. Everything about this place- I love. Sure, seating is only limited to the picnic tables outside, but the whole point it to grab a quick sammy and goooo. The lines are long during lunch hour, but they are efficient and quick. Ingredients are fresh, and most are locally sourced. My favorite sandwiches are their house-made mozzarella/basil/tomato sammy which they offer daily, and their occasional roasted lamb market sandwich with arugula. No matter what you get, the flavors are fantastic and the bread is so rustic and delicious. 

Most of the time I ended up eating half and sharing with someone else because they are filling. When my appetite isn't too big, I go for their foccaccia of the day, which changes daily but is no less amazing. Particular favorites utilized ingredients such as roasted shallots, dried figs, poached plums, goat cheese, and so on...it's hearty enough to be meal on its own and it's under $4.

They also offer a couple of market salads, which I never really tried and they've got a selection of artisinal/gourmet cheeses and pantry goods imported from Italy. If they've still got some vanilla bean pudding-- go for it!

Notes: Parking is tight as they share with Lux. They've got parking on both sides (bigger lot is off of Turney) and ample street parking on Turney as well. They close as 3PM, so get there early, and they are only open Tues-Sat. You can call orders in ahead of time, and if you want to eat your lunch inside of Lux, they allow it!

The pizzas, bread, and dessert we had from Pane Bianco by Chris Bianco were all amazing.

The Wiseguy Pizza $18.00 was as good as I remember it. I realize now that I'm not a huge fan of pre-cooked, wood roasted, or caramelized onions on pizza because it's too sweet for me on pizza, but that's just me. The mozzarella and sausage were still amazing. The pizza crust is one of my favorite crusts out there. It's not too chewy, easy to bite through, and is perfectly cooked in the oven. I appreciated the black pepper grinders at every table. 

I don't typically order Margherita Pizza $15.00 because they don't have meat. But I knew that all the ingredients would be top notch, so I went for it. The sauce was very tasty. It tasted like pure pureed tomatoes. The mozzarella was perfectly salted. The basil amount was okay, but I need triple the amount of basil leaves.
