Beverage choices (especially low calorie caffeinated ones) are limited, but you can always run next door to Lux for an iced tea or coffee. Personally, I enjoy a sparkling mineral water to compliment my lunch here. 

In your lunch sack, you will find a sweet treat to finish your meal. Most recently, I had a dark chocolate cowboy boot. My favorite is when there is a French caramel. 

4 stars instead of 5 because: the limited beverage selection and, mostly, because seating is limited and outdoor only. 

On a nice day, they are a solid 5 stars, but lunch hour after a night of rain that has left the the wood benches damp enough to transfer or in 115 degree summer heat, they drop to 4 stars.
My first time here. Had the market sandwich, whatever I ate was outstanding, had amazing bacon, a perfect tomato and incredible bread. Not inexpensive, but worth it. I will be back.

Pane Bianco somehow got even cuter.  Since the last time we were here, they added a cool full service eat-in dining room where the cafe next door used to be. 

On this visit I had the Market Sandwich which this time was an Egg Fritata with spicy sopresota, manchego, tomato, greens and onion.  I actually thought the locally grown tomatoes were the star - much beefier and tastier than the grocery store tomatoes we get at home. I wanted more sopresota, but I got my fix with a piece of my sister-in-law's sopresota sandwich with aged provolone and wood-roasted onions. This is my favorite sandwich on the menu, which I ordered myself the last time we were at Pane Bianco. According to our server, the most popular sandwich is the mozzarella, followed by the sopresota.  I'd put all of these sandwiches up against any of the best sandwiches served anywhere.  Our kiddos loved the focaccia as well. 

They bake the awesome round bread in the wood-burning hearth you see when you walk in, they make and smoke the mozzarella on the premises and the veggies are locally sourced as well. Great place.  #amazingsandwiches

Pane Bianco is #7 on my speed dial, so I can call them and ask what their Market Sandwich of the day is!  My mom is #8.  Is that bad?

I have grown up eating italian sandwiches from my neighborhood, my entire life.  So ever since I moved here, I've been comparison shopping.  I still love Alpine, Gene's Deli, and Freddy's, but marone!   

The ingredients and preparations are simple, which puts them on another level.

Menu-simple and straightforward.
Bread-disturbing
Mozzarella texture and taste- truly homemade.
Tomatoes- Sea salt and Fresh Ground Pepper!
Price-a tad high, but I would almost pay double.
Thank You. 

I'm pushing #7 right now, to see if there is anything to sway me away from getting the Mozzarella or Sopressata sandwich today.

I learned what a real tomato tastes like eating Pane Bianco's tomato, moz and basel sandwich.  It actually smells like a tomato is supposed to smell like.
But as good as the sandwiches are, my favourite is the slice of flat bread pizza they sell.  I don't know how they do it, but the tomatoes seem to meld into the bread with some sort of chemical effect that, along with the freshly-made and freshly-baked dough tastes even better than traditional pizza.

Since I was heading to Lux Coffeehouse next door, I decided to check out Pane Bianco since it got such great reviews, and I love sandwiches! However, they have a very limited menu (4-5 sandwich choices and 3 salad choices), and nothing on the menu that day looked that great to me. I did like that they had a separate side for to-go orders, since that really speeds up the process. I opted for the Market Sandwich, which rotates ingredients. On that day it was: Egg Frittata, Arugula, Balsamic Vinaigrette ($11, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pane-bianco-phoenix?select=TRYOU_BlbS4tSff1H1O6iQ#TRYOU_BlbS4tSff1H1O6iQ), which was very average. The egg frittata was overcooked and the edges were very dry, and it also didn't have much flavor. I regret not going with the caprese since I love fresh mozzarella. In any case, I would probably be willing to come back and give Pane Bianco another try. They have a little parking lot area, so you should be fairly easy to find a spot. The staff seemed friendly, but they spent a lot of time chatting with each other since I was the only customer in during that time. Luckily I was going next door for coffee, because it got a little awkward standing there while they were conversating with each other.

Absolutely delicious!!  We stopped in for a quick lunch on Sunday and left feeling fully satisfied.  The atmosphere is open and relaxing and the staff is really good.  I definitely suggest you try the seasonal Prickly Pear beer on tap... it was perfect for the hot summer day!!  I'll be bringing my friend up there just to share that delectable seasonal beer.

Went here with a friend.    I had the "market salad," which included prosciutto, pomegranates, persimmons, among many other ingredients.   It is amazing  how putting the right ingredients together affects the dish one eats.   It was one of the "specials" of the day.   Marco, the brother of the owner, was most attentive.    The person I went with is from New York.   Marco is from NY.    He is quite friendly, and is very good at making his guests feel welcome.     My friend told me about their pizzas.    Next time I shall not be distracted by their specials of the day and order the pizza.

I stopped in here for lunch on the way to a Dbacks day game.  As mentioned by others, the tomato, mozz and basil sandwich is awesome.  I sat outside at one of the picnic tables and enjoyed every bite.

I can't say enough about this place. The sandwiches are the best simple sandwiches you will ever eat. The fresh ingredients make a big difference. My favorite is the good old mozzarella and tomatoes with basil. It's so refreshing and addicting. I get cravings for this sandwich like I was a pregnant women. I also love the fresh baked bread you can purchase.
Bread is fabulous. mozarella sandwich great. parking is difficult. staff nice . pleasant.

Loved this place- hipster-ish sandwich shop (perfect considering the location). The inside decor was awesome- mismatched shabby chic chairs and tables. We shared a sandwich and salad and both were great. Very fresh, tasted freshly made, and with great ingredients. The service was super friendly even though we showed up in bike helmets and all sweaty after having ridden 12 miles there. The gentleman manning the take-out counter happily grabbed enough water to refill all of our backpacks and chatted us up while we were waiting for our sandwiches. He knew the menu and had his own recommendations for what we might enjoy, which were spot on.

My family and I have been eating at Pizzeria Bianco for years as a special occasion place, so when I heard they had a sandwich shop I had to visit! It was definitely a bit of a drive, since I'm all the way out in Glendale right now, but I figured it would probably be worth it. 

They have a very small storefront; the bulk of the space is the baking operation and sandwich-making in the back - and I could tell because it was all open. I love being able to see the food I'm about to eat being made (who doesn't?) and seeing/smelling the fresh bread coming out of the oven definitely upped my anticipation. The staff was really friendly, which is always a plus. I ordered two sandwiches, the tuna and the soppressata, and they were ready within 5 minutes, still all nice and warm. Unfortunately, I had to cart them all the way back to Glendale so my boyfriend could get his, so I didn't get to taste mine fresh.

He said his was awesome, and had never had roasted red peppers that were so delicious, but I was slightly more on the fence about my tuna. Not that it wasn't good, it was a great quality sandwich and the bread was amazing. I think it was just the flavor combination for me, I guess I'm used to my tuna being seasoned a certain way, and having something so different wasn't quite up my alley. But knowing their quality now, I will certainly be back to try something else.

I will say that the price was slightly high, which I expected, but I was a little disappointed that the prices on their website are incorrect. My sandwich was $9.50 and my boyfriend's was $9, instead of the $8 posted on their website. 

In summary, good food, good experience, I'd come back if I had some extra money in my bank account and was craving a delicious sandwich on high quality bread.

Yum, yum, yum. The tomato/mozzarella/basil sandwich is to-die-for, the tuna is crazy good too (in either sandwich or salad form). I love that they always have something different for dessert or a local produce treat. One of the girls at the counter has the personality of a cardboard box, but the other girl makes up for it. They have limited hours so make sure they are open before you go or you will be disappointed- especially when you read the mouth-watering menu that is posted in the window. They also have a good selection of drinks to go with your lunch. It is a little pricey and there is no where to sit but outside. My advice is to go with a friend and get two different things to split so for your money you can experience twice as much. You are allowed to go next door to Lux to eat if you buy something there too. I took off one star just based on the lack of seating, especially when trying to dine with a 2 year old.

They do it right and the hype is true.  This is not the spot for the world famous pizza which you hear about (although you can get it here at night).  That's another restaurant owned by the same people.  This restaurant is simple and classic.  It's super fresh and everything is made by hand.  

I spoke with the owner and he has a machine that grinds his own flour and everything.  If you like authentic Italian food this is a must stop.  Everything you order will make you so effing delighted you won't be able to see straight.  If the owner is there talk to him about food.  He will bring you things to try.  He's happy you are happy about his food....and that makes eating a pleasure.

I have worked downtown for years, and this spot is a favorite. All of the sandwiches are good, and take out is super easy. (I work on a lot of campaigns - live off take out). On the rare times that I am able to sit outside, everything is clean and run efficiently.

Pane Bianco came up as "highly recommended" for lunch on my Yelp app and is close to work so I decided to stop in for lunch and to try somewhere new. Parking was a bit tight and not a lot of spaces in general but was luckily able to snatch one. There are two sides to enter, one for to-go and one for eat in. I walked inside and the décor was so cute, very vintage meets farmhouse feel. They wanted to stick me at a long table with another party of 2 but felt awkward so I went to sit up at the bar, since there weren't any small tables to choose from. Service was very fast, ordered a diet coke but received a coca cola "light", which in my opinion does not taste like diet coke. Oh well. 

I read their menu (which is VERY limited) and looked on their board for the specials of the day. There were a total of 4 sandwiches, 4 salads and 2-3 "bar size" options to choose from and that's all. Only 2 of the options had meat in them so I was a bit disappointed with that and neither option was what I wanted. I ultimately ordered the market sandwich, which was a roasted tomato, arugula and goat cheese on focaccia bread. I think the servers were bored because it wasn't busy and they kept circling around waiting for something to do, very weird. Maybe I noticed it more because I was alone? Anyways, I got my food within 5 minutes and it came with a tiny serving of coleslaw, which was made with apples and red onions. The sandwich was fine but nothing amazing...coleslaw was different but ate it in like 3 bites. I was still hungry after my lunch so decided to order the flourless chocolate cake for dessert...couldn't pass that up! It was really great, came with a vanilla bean cream on top to balance out the richness of the cake. I got the bill and it was $22 so not cheap...the market sandwich with no meat on it was $12! Yikes. 

All in all, I just came to realize that Pane Bianco is just not for me. I know they have great ingredients and does have a certain appeal, very downtown. I did notice the dinner options and was curious if dinner time is a better time to go, since options were things I actually wanted to eat (stuffed peppers, posole, pasta, pizza). So, I wouldn't not recommend it I just don't think I would come back. Glad I tried it though!

I protested going to this place.  The thought of a restaurant with only three sandwich choices and no substitutions; to a picky eater this is a recipe for disaster.   However, when a colleague offered to take me there for my birthday I decided to give it a try and all I have to say is WOW!

I had the tomato mozzarella sandwich and until that exact moment I did not like mozzarella cheese.  The combination of ripe tomatoes, cheese and basil was like heaven in my mouth.  The bread was a perfect combination of crisp but not hard to bit into.  I also loved the different drink options besides soda. 

It loses a star for seating issues, the place was packed and seating is at picnic tables outside only.  We had to wait for a place to squeeze in between two parties on a picnic table.  I guess that's the price you pay for reasonably priced, fresh, delicious food.  Next time, I'll take it back to my office.

I am always thrilled to discover quality and unique non-chain eateries in the phoenix area.  The artisan bread the sandwich was assembled on was delicious.  I ordered the mozzarella, tomato, basil sandwich.  You could taste the quality mozzarella but i found the ingredients would have popped more and melted better together if it was seasoned with salt and pepper.

The menu is minimal.  4 or 5 sandwich options with one being the market sandwich that changes daily.  They also offer 3 salads.

The brand of ginger ale they offered was pleasantly delicious.  It is not as sweet or artificial tasting as CanadaDry but also not as bitter and sharp as other brands.

The workers there were friendly and the wait was minimal.  It is a destination restaurant.  There is not much around there.  Good size parking lot.  There is no seating in the restaurant but there are benches outside.
Totally enjoyed a wonderful antipasto with delicious grilled veggies. I had nutmeg Italian ice for dessert, made on the premises. Unusual and very yummy.

I've heard so many good things about this place. It seemed like it may be a favorite Phoenix lunch joint for cuisine aficionados and it looks like it is for some, but was only a-ok to me.

There was nothing gross or disgusting to me about the food. It was made with quality ingredients and had a decent taste...I guess I just felt that the food wasn't worth the price. Especially because I've had better tasting food for lesser or equal value at other places (such as La Grande Orange or La Boca).

Overall, this place isn't bad. I just feel it's been hyped up and is the "trendy" place to eat.

Love is in the air... yes, Valentines Day is around the corner, but the love is really about the spontaneous lunch date I had the other day at Pane Bianco.

For those wondering, my date was with my husband.  We left the baby at home (with a babysitter of course), and went out for a few hours to enjoy the beautiful weather.  After a stop at the Downtown Phoenix Public Market, we were both hungry and finally agreed to head to PB.  I hate to admit this, but it was my first time there... I had high expectations and PB delivered!  

We sat outside on the picnic tables instead of taking advantage of the full service inside.  We shared a tomato mozzarella sandwich and a tuna salad.  Both were delicious!  Melt in your mouth delicious!  We also brought home their market sandwich for our babysitter (aka my mother-in-law).  It was a vegetable sandwich which she said was delicious.

I'd heard the menu was limited, which it was, but there was still plenty to choose from.  I can't wait to return for lunch or dinner... and perhaps to take advantage of their private little room in back.  Anyone up for a little dinner party at Pane Bianco?!

As far as quick, easy, and casual lunch goes, this place is as good as it gets. YUM. After hearing rave reviews about this place from coworkers, I finally made it over there. The dine-in side is very cute and looks in theme with the other Bianco establishments. The drink of the day was some melon/prosecco goodness but since i had to go back to work, I didn't not imbibe.

I had my mind made up that I would go with the mozz sandwich recommendation but if the market sandwich (sandwich of the day) was a meatball sandwich, that would be my choice. The market sandwich was eggplant and creamy burrata (which my coworker had and really enjoyed) so I went with the mozz. Simple clean flavors are the best. The mozzarella was so creamy rich, the basil was fresh and the tomatoes -- perfectly vine-ripe --  a great balance to the mozz. Yum. Seasoned ever so slightly with some salt and pep on focaccia that is not of this earth. All the Bianco restaurants kill it with their bread game. From the bread and butter, to the pizza, to the focaccia -- its all phenomenal. Honestly, I have never been a fan of focaccia but i know now its because I have only had sh*tty focaccia up until this point. 

Let me not forget the iced tea -- as I have I said in yelp reviews of other places that I am an avid iced tea enthusiast and sometimes a star hinges on the iced tea. This iced tea is delicious -- no Gold Peak or Nestea crap here. I forgot to ask our server (an ethnic Sam Smith look alike) what kind of tea it was because I would buy it and brew it at home. 

Service was friendly and fast. We arrived early enough to find a seat and parking. In nicer weather, they have a fair amount of seating outside as well. We also saw Chris Bianco there! A lil' celeb chef sighting is exciting for sure.

When I worked downtown, I used to lunch here at least twice a week. Since moving away, I miss the tomato and fresh mozzarella sandwich so much I dream about it sometimes. Nowadays I can only get down here during dinner time, which is a bummer, because the sandwich side of things closes up at night. However, there are no lunch rush lines at night, and the food is fantastic. You can get a Pizzeria Bianco classic pie here without the crazy wait time of that shop. Last time I came they told me they were serving the fresh mozzarella for dinner with prosciutto instead of tomatoes. It was a revelation.

I have GREAT news! I heard firsthand that Pane Bianco is getting their liquor license...YELPERS REJOICE! 

Besides that excellent news, I am happy to report that Pane Bianco's sandwiches are still as delicious as ever. Like everyone else here, I am slightly obsessed with the mozzarella sandwich. I have both dined in and ordered my sandwich to go. I noticed that my bread was toasted when eating in the restaurant, whereas the chewy, soft bread was left alone when I grabbed my sandwich to go. I definitely prefer it untoasted and plan to order it that way in the future. 

I love everything about this place. The space is funky, yet somewhat minimalistic. I like that it is small and can only hold so many people. There's also the outdoor picnic table option if it's not a gazillion degrees out. The service is great and my husband and I are always welcomed and made to feel at home. Others before me have commented on the lack of menu options...while true, the items that they do offer are so delicious that I have no complaint. The drink selection has also improved based on what yelpers before me have said. They had a few soda selections as well as sparkling water (and soon to be alcohol!). Yeah, the prices seem a bit high when you realize you're paying $8.50 for a sandwich, but let's be honest...the quality is totally worth it and you can get like two meals out of that bad boy. Plus, when I think about other less-awesome restaurants around the valley (hello Paradise Bakery), the price is surprisingly comparable. I'll take my deliciously fresh bread, creamy mozzarella, and flavorful tomato any day for nine-ish bucks. 

So yeah, nothing negative for me to say. Shocking, right? I will continue to be back here regularly. And with Lux right next door, what's not to love about this little central Phoenix stop? Plus, they're going to have alcohol soon! I'll be on pins and needles 'til then...

Pane Bianco is one of my favorite pizza places in the valley.  I know it is the little sister to Pizzeria Bianco, but this was the first restaurant we tried and it has become our favorite.  

The pizzas are brick oven style.  The crust (which is great!) is very thin and perfectly cooked with maybe a slight amount of char.  The sauce and topping combinations that they serve are all great.  The margerita pizza is our favorite.  I also really enjoy their Rosa pizza, and I usually despise onions!  The Biancoverde is also great.  You really can't go wrong with a pizza.

Once, we had an amazing vegetarian lasagna.  It was light with lots of veggies in it.  More recently, we ordered the lasagna on the menu, but it was much richer with TONS of cheese.  It was good, but not as good as what we had previously had.  

Great place to eat on Central & I've never had to wait.  Thanks!

No pain here.
Just Pane

Sopressato is unreal. Salty meat, creamy cheese and the best sandwich bread on earth, made by Chris Biancos brother. These guys are genius.

Friendly female server. Seems like Bianco keeps his employees a long time. Must be a nice man.

The side salad is perfect with the sandwich. 
Wish there would have been more
But oh well

I've never eaten here, just had a friend describe to me how he was kicked out for "speaking spanish".  A bit in shock that a business in America thinks this is helpful in anyway.  If it's true then I suggest nobody eat here but Separatist douchebags.
Super nice staff, very cute decor.  A hip, cool place.  Not too crowded at lunch

So they now have the entire building and a dinner menu.  Alcohol license pending.

Now is the time to sneak in for some of the best food in the Valley.

We went 3:30PM Friday, 

-wild arugula salad with roasted beets, goat cheese and toasted pecans
-pizza margarita
-roast pig, she apologized that it had just come out of the overn and was resting for 10 minutes.

Absolute heaven.

We left at 5PM Friday, still almost empty place.  I must be in bizarro world.

I wish my budget allowed me to eat there every day until the alcohol license arrives.  Or bizarro world stays put.

A good mozzarella sandwich for Arizona but NOWHERE NEAR the one I had back in Jersey at Joe Leone's in Pt. Pleasant. 
I had to park down the street, even on a Saturday at 2pm. Paid $20 to take home a Mozzarella/tomato& basil, and a Soppressata/provalone& roasted pepper. The hubby agreed: they were good, not great. Had to add salt & pepper to the mozz sandwich; not a good thing... 
Bread is very good, but it's that tough, rustic thin focaccia style which makes my mouth sore from chewing. Not a big fan of that. Also, they were sold out of the Sandwich Special of the Day so that left me with exactly 3 to coose from. Not enough variety.

Yes, glad I finally tried Mr. Bianco's famed sandwich spot.  Added bonus was that they now serve pizza next door, no more 2 hour wait. 

The food is fresh and delicious.  Every dish is a culinary masterpiece and a palette pleas-er.  I would suggest the Mozzarella Sandwich (a Caprese on bread), but always check out the daily special.  Decent selection of craft beers and wine.  Just go and enjoy.

I love this place, the chicken salad sandwich just melts in my mouth.  I litter my bought six loads of breads from the rack. Cleaned out their breads in minutes.  Must go there if you want a good sandwich!

If you're looking for a higher than average priced sandwich that comes with more arugula than tuna, come here. I'm guessing that the 8$ I paid for the sandwich is more for covering the hip little piece of chocolate, the napkin and the overall "look" of the restaurant than it is for the sandwich. 

Is this an 8$ sandwich? No. I'd say more of a 6.50 w/ tax. Some points:

- Yes, the tuna is tasty. Is it AMAZING, or heaven, or any other word used before in the other reviews to signify that this HAS to be the GREATEST tuna ever? No. 
- Bread is really good. I'll give credit where it's due. 
- Way too much arugula on the sandwich. Seriously, I opened it up and had to go looking for the tuna. Don't think I didn't catch that the tuna is all in the middle so it looks like there is a lot but really there isn't. 

I'm sure that tons and tons of people love this place because it's slightly better than most places in Phoenix. That's the thing about beating the competition. You don't have to be mind-blowingly amazing. You just have to try 5% harder than the rest. 

This is 5% more of an effort, and it shows, but let's not pretend that Pane Bianco is the next greatest thing ever even if some of the other reviewers will have you believe it. 

I'll give it one more try and if I'm not satisfied with their mozzarella sandwich, I most likely will not go back. I didn't even finish the sandwich I just bought which makes me mad because I really was looking forward to it. Maybe I'm not a foodie or I don't appreciate subtle flavors or whatever, but I was not happy with this sandwich.

+ 1 for the chocolate, -2 for the overabundance of arugula and not enough tuna, +1 for the bread, + 1 for the fast service.

So disappointed in this long time favorite spot. I bit into rocks (yes plural) when eating the bean salad that comes with their sandwiches. I went back and showed a napkin of rocks to the gentleman behind the counter. He said the manager would be right out. After several minutes, someone (not the manager) explained that it wasn't their fault because their beans are organic, and this can just happen...essentially just evading responsibility. The manager refunded my lunch. No one ONCE apologized. My teeth still hurt. I'm so disappointed in an establishment that has previously always exceeded my customer service expectations. The friends I was with chose not to eat here based upon this experience. Sad that their mishandling of the situation lost them their business, and my future business.

Shortest review ever.

Awesome mozzarella, super fresh basil, tomatoes that taste like tomatoes, real bread. These are a few of my favorite things. 

Anyone who gives this place less than 4 stars - don't go back, you don't deserve this place. Go play in traffic or DIAF or something.

I have been dying to try Pizzeria Bianco, which supposedly makes the best pizza in America.  I have heard horror stories of people waiting for several hours to get a slice.  After exploring their web site, I learned of their sister restaurant, Pane Bianco, which appeared to serve the same pizza.  I called and confirmed the pizza is indeed the same and they are far less crowded.  We went around 6 pm on a Saturday and there plenty of available tables.  Our waitress was very accommodating and friendly.  We had an amazing vegetable board, some salads and a variety of pizzas.  Was it the best pizza I have ever had?  No, but it was definitely good.  Absolutely loved the rustic ambiance, picnic tables, tableware.  Would love to go back for happy hour!

The 5 Stars let you know where I stand. Uniquely awesome sammiches on crazy fresh Umbrian-style bread. You cannot go wrong.

So just a tip:
keep calling and checking to see if one of the following is the market sammich that day.

 - crumbled sausage and melted mozzarella

 - pulled pork

 - pulled lamb

 If it is one of the above, in that order, drop whatever you're doing and get there as fast as you can. Also, do not ignore the market focaccia. Even if it just looks like a pile of veggies on a sheet pan pizza, it is fantastic.

I've never had a bad meal at Pane after four years... maybe five. From the moment I set foot inside, it took me back to a hip, LA kinda vibe. Small, not a lot of menu choices, fresh, organic food selections... and BUBBLE UP... the Malibu of pop, people. 

The food is simply done and quite delish. I usually alternate between the Sopressata and the Mozzarello/Tomato/Basil sandwiches, or go with the Caprese Salad. They make the bread onsite, the basil is grown locally as is most of the veggies. 

The crowds get pretty big after 11:30 a.m. and don't die down until around 1:45 p.m. They close at 3 p.m because Chris would head down to Pizzeria Bianco for a busy evening. Apparently he is taking a back seat due to some health concerns. I hope it doesn't affect the food quality but I'm sure his staff will continue his tradition of fresh, tasty and simple. 

** Word of advice: Do not crave this place in August. They shut down for a month-long vacation!! Oh, dread!

I am at home sick today, and actually had a chance to try Pane Bianco.  I was not excited to get out of my pajamas and head down there, but I am glad that I did so.  Like so many other reviewers have mentioned, the mozzarella sandwich is pretty top notch.  I enjoyed every bite.  If I'm craving a good sandwich, I will definitely head to Pane Bianco, if they are open... which leads me to my next point:

I am easily annoyed by hours as minimal as 11-3.  I wish that businesses that put out such a great product would realize that if they were open longer, more people would be lucky enough to enjoy their product.  I appreciate that they are open on Saturdays, but I'm still docking a star for lack of hours open.

Chris Bianco, you knocked this one out of the park. Every time I go I get the mozzarella, tomato, basil sandwich. Their ingredients are so fresh and delicious, there is really nothing quite like it. But it's their bread what makes it especially fantastic and unique. To people visiting Phoenix, you should make a point of going here, and to Phoenicians who have not been, shame on you.

If you're into family-style seating with strangers, limited menus, not having a drink with your meal, and small portions with large price tags, it's perfect.

I hope to go back when they have their liquor licence; that'll give it at least one more star (depending on how many drinks I have ;)

This place is fantastico! Try their goat cheese and spinach Pane. This is no ordinary sandwich, the bread is baked in a wood oven fresh on the spot, very European style food and drink. Interesting Building too very Noveux.

why did i wait so long to try pane bianco?! i opted for the mozzarella tomato basil sandwich. bread is yummy and rustic - crusty on the outside, soft on the inside - absolute perfection. the house-made mozzarella was some of the best i've ever had. local tomatoes were perfectly ripe and plentiful. the basil was fragrant and flavorful - a real treat. i don't know what else to say except it was amazing. oh and that the yummy, nutty, caramel-y surprise in the bottom of my bag was delish. i'm hooked.
Love this place. The mozzarella sandwiches are amazing. Great customer service. The veggies are fresh and the service is fast.

4/5 Stars.

Drinks: Ordered the Mudshark pumpkin ale (on tap), which the server was happy to let me sample before ordering! Not only is the tap handle adorable (I'm a sucker for pretty aesthetics), the beer itself was exceptional! Not too heavy or overly spiced, which can be the issue in my opinion with a lot of pumpkin brews. It was very smooth, and a new favorite of mine!

Food: We came for their dinner menu (after 4pm), so we will definitely be back to try their lunch menu options as well. I ordered the "Meatball Hero", which was a giant meatball sandwich with a side salad! The bread was just the right amount of crispy and their sauce recipe is delicious! We also ordered the "Lasagna al Forno", which boats the same sauce and cheese melted on top! Both great choices, but the lasagna was slightly better in my opinion. I love their bread as well, which seems to be quite the hit. The place was very quiet inside on a Saturday afternoon, but several customers showed up for pick up orders of just bread! For dessert, we ordered the "Tres Leches Cake". Which is ALWAYS delicious. I liked the added touch of almonds sprinkled on top... the only thing that could make it better would be caramel sauce!

Ambiance/Service: The decor was exceptional and very cute! I loved the mix of rustic feels in with all the textures. The music softly played in the background and our server was very friendly. He was not over bearing but still very attentive. He had great recommendations!

Overall, can't wait to come back and try the lunch menu! This place would be a great location for a group outing as well!
Just bought some bread here to take home. EXCELLENT! Other than my own homemade Biga, best in the city.
Whats to say that hasn't already been said! BEST Sandwiches EVER!
Great lunch spot, really yummy sandwich and very shareable.

Pane Bianco is one of those neighborhood places that we've wanted to try for years but somehow haven't gotten to.  So I suggested it for lunch today and off we went.  We were very pleased all around.  The ambiance is great- kind of rustic Italian chic with low and high tables, a bar, and a takeout area next door.  The service was fantastic.  It took maybe 3 minutes to get our food, although sandwiches and salads aren't too taxing to make, and it wasn't crowded.  Still, it was noted and much appreciated.  I got the Caprese salad.  I debated between that and the sandwich, but finally decided on the salad because it did come with bread (which I definitely wanted to try, it being PANE Bianco, but sometimes sandwiches are just too bready).  I spent 2 weeks a couple of years ago literally eating my way through Italy on Caprese salads, and this was as good as many and better than some.  The tomatoes were red ripe and tasty.  The mozzarella was fresh, and it had just the right amount of basil, olive oil, and salt and pepper.  Yum- thinking about it now makes me hungry all over again.  The bread was as expected, fresh and crusty.  I also got the pickled vegetables, which were good and interesting.  It was a plate of baby carrots, onions, cauliflower, and peas pickled in what seemed to be apple cider vinegar, so they were sweet and sour at the same time.  Sweet Pea got the Soppresata sandwich, which came with the chile Soppreseta today (which was great, as we are both notorious spicy hounds), and he really enjoyed it.  It also came with sort of a saucy cold bean salad, I think they were lima or fava beans, which he didn't like but I LOVED.  I ate all of his too.  They serve Mexican sodas but aren't too precious about it- always appreciated.  We will definitely be going back, and I will go by the takeout for a loaf of bread when I'm having a party.  Good to know there is a good bread bakery around!

At first, I was a little disappointed in the menu selection. Only three sandwiches plus two daily specials? And then, no normal drinks? All a brother wanted was a diet coke but they . . .didn't carry coke or pepsi? What kind of restaurant was this?

As it turned out, a damn good one. And then I realized, how dare I presume I will know better what I want to eat than Chris Bianco, my favorite chef and purveyor of restaurants in the Valley? It would be like telling your favorite band how to play their instruments.

It makes much more sense, and works out much better in the end, if you just let them do what they do and sample the final product. 

And the no coca cola, by the way, is a great call. They have an entirely organic alternative with no caffeine called China Soda that was more than satisfactory. 

So if you're not sure, ask whoever is working for a recommendation and trust that Bianco will deliver.

Finally got around to checking out this place for lunch time on my day off - they close early so I rarely get to make it to these hip sandwich spots..

Despite the tiny menu of items, my friend and I managed to find two sandwhiches that sounded delicious.  Not sure what to expect for $8, I ordered the tuna and she got the tomato and mozzarella. we also picked up the tea/lemonade which brought us up to a little over $11 each. normally my cheap ass does not spend more than $5 for lunch (subway, anyone?) so my expectations were high from the second my card was swiped.

the sandwiches were made quickly and came packed up to go in a very cute bag. we grabbed a table outside and dug in. the bread that they oven bake is delicious and the sandwich was surprisingly big and filling. the tuna was made without mayo (which i prefer) and the tomato/mozzarella was fresh, juicy, and delicious.  the tea was refreshing and tart, just how i like it.

for $8, I'd expect at least a bag of kettle chips to go on the side, or something. i find it weird to eat a sandwich without a side, especially without some salt and vinegar chips. this place probably gets quite crowded during the break of lunch, but we went it wasn't too bad at 1:30pm. more seating would be nice, and hopefully they get some misters going for summer lunch patrons cuz you're right in the sun.
I'm pretty sure if you could eat heaven...this is what it would taste like.

I have dreams about the mozzarella on the Caprese style sandwich.  Seriously.  
And the Soppressata is the PERFECT compliment...if you're coming as a twosome order both and share.  YUM.

This place opened when I was in high school across the street so I've tried all of it. Their mozzarella and bread are both made fresh, the mozzarella is so creamy you'll want to add it to all their sandwiches. Their bread is crisp and wood fired and their sandwhiches are huge. When you order it to go they give you a small candy, a super soft and fancy napkin, and your sandwich all bundled up and just waiting to be unwrapped and devoured.

When I first started going there they also offered foccasia options that changed daily which were absolutely delicious but they no longer serve them. Since they expanded into what was once Lux, their menu also expanded and now they include full pizzas and more entree options, along with a full dining room.

All of their ingredients are incredibly fresh, and many can be bought inside. Many of their ingredients are obtained from local farms (including Blue Sky) so you know you're not just eating something delicious and supporting a local business but also eating healthy and organic.

If its got that Bianco name, you know its worth the price. My one complaint is that they did away with the foccasias and the lamb market sandwich which was by far my favorite item on the menu.

I love everything I've had at Pane Bianco. Their food is fresh and delicious and the place is absolutely adorable. I was disappointed that they do not serve their pizzas at lunch time, and I do wish that they had a cheaper side salad to go along with their entrees, but other than those two small complaints this place rocks!

I'm a big fan of the Bianco family. I can't believe it took me this long to discover Pane existed! (I frequent Pizzeria Bianco) 

They have two rotating taps and two constants. Today it was Four Peaks Hop Not and a SunBru if I remember correctly- then a sour and prickly pear wheat. I went with the sour for a nice refreshing kick in this AZ summer heat. The short beers are $3 and pints are $6. 

For lunch I ordered a fennel grapefruit salad which was like no other salad I've ever experienced. It was refreshing and light. Definitely a lighter lunch so I don't recommend if you are starving but a great pick for something unique and light! 

Our server was very pleasant and sweet. 

Will definitely be back soon to check out their dinner menu which looked killer.
Warning they close earlier than most restaurants so keep in mind!

I was recently turned on to Pane Bianco by a pervious chef I used to work for.
He had brought us in a Market Sandwich, and it was love at first bite.

I was hooked from then on! The freshly made food, the atmosphere and service is top notch.

And dinner now, forget it. Simple clean and delicious!

Pane Bianco doesn't offer a crazy-big menu, but you won't care about a huge selection after you take the first bite of your sandwich or salad. A brick oven in the center of the restaurant ensures fresh bread on a daily basis. It's crispy, chewy and delicious. 

The Market Sandwich varies on availability and price depending on what's fresh for whatever time of year you choose to dine there. You can purchase entire loaves of their famous sandwich bread to share with others or greedily scarf it down in a dark corner somewhere in a manner not unlike that of a starving badger.

Be prepared for a bit of a wait during the lunch time hours of the Monday - Friday white collar work week. The secret is out, but it's definitely worth the wait.

The sandwich and salad were good, but overpriced. However, the service was so bad, I won't be back. 

When we mentioned we'd like to move to the outside tables, the manager (?) said we couldn't take the silverware out there. Ummmm that's weird, but fine. I complied, left our silverware inside and proceeded out. Waited for him to bring us plastic ware as promised. 

After staring at our salads for a couple minutes, I poked my head back inside and he was chatting with another employee. Ok, just grabbed the silverware off the table to use until he brought us the required plastic forks. 15 mins later, we are done eating. Plastic forks never arrived. Refills of tea never arrived. Check never arrived. So my friend goes inside to pay the bill and mentions that we were completely ignored. This same manager proceeds to scold her for bringing out the forks! Wow. Not cool. 

Still not sure what the big deal was about the forks, but it really doesn't matter. I will not be returning here or to pizzeria bianco.

I was in Arizona this past weekend and stumbled on to this quaint little restaurant -- I Hab a chicken dish cooked in a tangerine sauce and these fabulous beans like fava beans and a salad with onions and red cabbage oh my god I thought I had died and gone to heaven - not to mention the Bar tender and the hostess who served us -- thank you Pane Bianco ... My friend had a pizza and it was so fresh all the  ingrediates  were great !!!!

Quality trumps quantity. That's their philosophy regarding menu design, a ballsy move for any restaurant. Fortunately for us, they can back it up with amazing craft! Their sandwiches are top notch, thanks to amazing freshly baked bread and quality ingredients (Soppressata, FTW).

Notes: Outdoor seating with misters only, nothing special; You won't find high fructose corn syrup in their soda selection; Their sister restaurant, Pizza Bianco, is also ridiculously good and nationally recognized.

Pane Bianco has changed in recent years - and they have only made the place more wonderful. I appreciate the expansion, as it makes the place a wonderful spot to meet friends for lunch without feeling cramped or overheated (by sitting outside). The french press coffee is to die for, and I can't wait to come back and try dinner! I had the soppressata which was just as delicious as I remembered from 8 years ago. And yes, I am a vegetarian!

I also purchased some Hayden Flour Mill pizza flour that I cannot wait to try! It's incredible to me that they mill all that flour out back! Talk about eating local - it's locally grown wheat, milled right there in the back, packaged under their roof and sold to you. It's like a dream. So go - grab some to-go, meet friends, take your kids, and eat. good. food.
Incredible gourmet pizza, tons of rich flavor but ultimately light food. Lovely, interesting atmosphere and attentive, helpful staff. Try it before word gets out and it becomes tough to get in.

We had just flown into Phoenix around lunch, and this was on the way to our destination so we decided to stop to try it. Pizzeria Bianco is always a stop when we come to town because we love it! This place was quite confusing. It looked fast casual, so we ordered at the register then asked if we should sit down or wait there or what because it wasn't clear to us. The cashier wasn't even sure. "Um, I guess I can  take your name." What do they usually do?? My friends waited up there while I grabbed a table on the other side. I could feel a vibe that me sitting at the table was clearly a problem from the mean looks I was getting from the server and that cashier when they talked to each other, but they never actually addressed anything with me. Were we supposed to sit outside? I still have no idea what we did wrong, and if we didn't understand "the way" of things there, please put up instructional signs or provide direction when we ask for clarification. It was decently busy, but we were clearly a huge inconvenience for the employees.

The mozzarella sandwich, pizza, and farmer's salad were good, clean tasting. Nothing that blew us away, but certainly with the lack of helpful service, we will just stick with the other pizzeria locations.

Also, the shared parking lot gets quite busy around lunch, beware!

I loved this place except for the limited choices.  But I think if there were more options, it might mean more people, a longer wait and REALLY no place to sit.  

It may be off of a nasty busy street, but sitting at the picnic table under the sun eating my sandwich, I felt like I was somewhere else.  I figured out on my second trip to get an ice tea next door at Lux....free refills!

Great bread baked on site? 

Super fresh mozzarella, tomatoes & basil?

Available fresh fruit and salads.

This place is right up the alley for those that are looking for a healthier alternative to lunch in CenPho.  

My only beef with Pane Bianco is the lack of choice.  They have a couple sandwiches, a couple salads and that's about it.  Now, what they do make is really good (along with the caprese sandwich, I suggest the sopprasetta- amazingly good salami- and provolone), I just wish they made more of it.  

Also, be aware, this isn't a sit-down place.  You order, pay, have a quick convo with one of the friendly staffmembers and take away.  From there, you can choose to take it with you to wherever or eat on the picnic benches shared with Lux with the lovely backdrop of Central Ave construction.

We were a party of eight and enjoyed our dinner outing. I had the pizza Margherita and it was delicious. Our waiter took great care of us. It was a very busy Thursday evening but we had fun and did not wait long for our meals.

I have found both the sandwiches and pizza to be great.  The salads are tasty too.  Last time I had the watermelon and fennel salad.  I had never had that combination before and it was very refreshing.  Perfect for summer.

Love, love, love this place. The sandwiches are to die for.. every one of them. The freshest of ingredients, locally sourced and so authentic an Italian food experience. Freshly made bread in wood fired ovens...how else should bread be made? I stop here at ever opportunity and am NEVER disappointed.

I just don't get those who would rate this place with less then 5 stars. That is simply injustice to the place, to the fans of Bianco and to the extraordinary FOOD being served there!
You are getting a sandwich with old world brick oven wood fire cooked bread and local organic ingredients for $8 dollars and you are complaining about the cars passing by outside!!! And you are in the middle of the desert! Give me a break!

Pane Bianco is to sandwiches what Pizza Bianco is to pizzas, namely heaven on earth. 

Both share Chris Bianco's dedication to using only the freshest, locally-sourced ingredients.  Pane Bianco features home-made bread baked in on-site wood ovens, hand made mozzarella, basil and greens out of Chris's own garden, and high quality meats from locally owned Schneider sausage. You can't get more local, or better quality than this. 

Pane Bianco has the added benefit of being a sandwich counter, which means you don't have to wait hours for a taste of deliciousness.  Although as others have mentioned at the lunch peak you may have to wait a few minutes; after all quality can't be rushed.  Take the opportunity to grab a coffee next door, or better yet, get to know your fellow sandwich fanatics--this is how community is built.  

If you are looking for an infinite selection of sub-par ingredients, or care more about price than quality, there are several other sandwich shops for you. so please don't bother coming here. And if the idea of ordering along side individuals who don't look like suburban clones scare you, this likely isn't your place either.  Check out one of the approximately 1,912 other sandwich shops in strip-malls throughout the Valley that cater to your tastes.  But if the freshest,and highest quality ingredients, knowledgeable service and authentic surroundings are are important to you, Pane Bianco is your type of place.

And if you do value quality over quantity, and authenticity over generica, but still feel that $8 bucks is a little steep for you in the current economic climate, share with a friend. The portions are generous enough to share and still feel satisfied. (although be sure to snap the chocolate treat for yourself!)

Maestro Chris Bianco whips up addictive sandwiches at his laboratory on Central Avenue. Ingredients are local and super-fantastic. Check out what today's market sandwich is -- if it's oven-roasted pork, buy it immediately. Don't miss the rice pudding.

Come here every time I come to Phoenix.  Got here at 12:15, they opened at noon.   Usual Fresh crispy bread was stale and cold. Must have been from yesterday.  Mozzarella soggy and drenched in so much oil on both sides.   Should have returned it but place so busy. :(. Super disappointed.

Are my reviews disappearing? I submitted a photo of this place back in September and it's still there, but I would swear I wrote a review too....

So add me to the mozzarella sandwich love.  I could eat the hell out of that thing every day of the week. Really wish I still lived close by so I could. The sandwich is so perfect, and so FRESH tasting unlike so many other "caprese" style sandwiches I have tasted. And for $8 you get a HUGE sandwich. Go get it, you wont be disappointed.

The piece of candy/chocolate they give you is a welcome touch :)

Anything Chris Bianco does is excellent and Pene Bianco is no exception.  My sopresetta sandwich today (2/13/2017) was delicious. But $3 for a can of Diet Coke is just greedy, man. Listen, I'm either realistic or cheap but I think $2 (!) is a lot. And we're not in f-ing Manhattan. 

When I questioned the cashier, how did a $10 sandwich and a Diet Coke could be $14, she was bashful, she was shy: she knew how I would react, as clearly others have before me, about a $ three dollar can of Diet Coke. You don't even need Costco; Fry's is about .25/each.  @$3 per can that's 12X profit.  TWELVE.

"You're entitled to all your success until you're not."

A $3 can of Diet Coke, my a$$, Chris. 
SHAME ON YOU!  SHAME!

Finally! The perfect caprese: tender housemade mozzarella, fresh pungent whole basil leaves, wonderful olive oil with a great bite and - most important - tomatoes that taste like real tomatoes. Also great as a sandwich on bread made in a wood fired oven. 

Smiling, attentive service in an immaculate dining area furnished with country funky mismatched tables and chairs.

If you love bread, this is the place for you. Sandwich for lunch and pizza for diner are perfect for me. All ingredients are so fresh out of the farm. I really love to come here and enjoy my food outside (only in the Fall/Spring though, not summer).

This place is awesome. 

For the guy who said you should go to Safeway instead for a sandwich, well, I'm guessing he probably thinks a steak at Applebees rivals a steak at City Hall. 

If you like turkey with mayo and mustard, you can't get that here. If you like to try new things with fresh ingredients, you might want to give this a try. Yes during the summer it is hot and they only have outdoor seating, but how about taking it to go and eating in your car? I've done in many times. 

As I say in my Pizzeria Bianco review, I now live in NYC but will take extended layovers in Phoenix gladly to stop at these two places. I have also scheduled meetings around these places being open! It's THAT good!

i always drive around this area searching for a new lunch spot but end up pulling in and getting the mozzarella, tomato, and basil sandwich. I have not been disappointed once, and today was no different.

The same pizza as Pizza Bianco but with no wait and plenty of seating.

I always get the Margrita pizza which is out of this world (with a very smokey taste).

Mexico cokes and community seating (as well as a bar to "belly up to").

Being a massive fan of Pizzeria Bianco, it's kind of hard to approach its spin-off establishment, Pane Bianco, from an unbiased standpoint. The restaurant's concept is slightly different than the pizzerias, as it seems to have garnered the reputation that, despite offering dinner, being more of a local lunch spot that primarily serves focaccia sandwiches.   

Over the years, I've had many sandwiches here and have never been disappointed. The house mozzarella and wood-roasted pepper combination, as well as the sopressata with aged provolone, are two of my absolute favorites. Every day, they also offer a market sandwich, which uses locally sourced ingredients. These can vary greatly, making it impossible to try everything that is offered. The fact is, few of these sandwiches ever disappoint. The ingredients are always top notch and the bread used for the sandwiches is what I've come to expect from Bianco. The only downside is that I do feel that prices are unreasonably high, especially considering I can get a whole pizza for what they charge for some of the market ones. There's a fine line between charging for quality as opposed to charging because of "brand" recognition. However, they do make every effort to source out locally, so you can't really complain too much.  

One of the true gems at Pane is their pizza al taglio. This is more along the lines of the traditional "by the slice" pizza squares that I feel is a style more people are familiar with. It's extremely well done and we insist on splitting a square of it during every single visit. On most days, they only offer a tomato sauce with cheese, but we've also spotted a Rosa-inspired version and ultra-cool variations that I've always wanted to try.

We've been putting off going to dinner here for the longest time. Mainly because the full-range of pizzas can be had elsewhere, meaning that we'd essentially just order the same thing that we'd order at Town and Country. Although they might have a few specials that are unique, the plates are pretty consistent with the pizzeria restaurants in terms of their alternative dishes. Desserts are also mostly what you'd find at their other locations, including the so-so flourless chocolate cake, delicious Italian ice, and if you're lucky, their superbly made "seasonal" tres leches cake that always seems to be in season.

Parking here can sometimes be a real pain! Not because of the Pane diners, but because the nearby Lux coffee shop clogs up the lot due to its massive popularity as a local hipster hangout. 

I might update this review when we finally cave and go here for dinner. But for now, Pane will remain one of my favorite lunch spots that I can't resist giving a strong recommendation to!

If I could eat one sand which for the rest of my life (can't have captain nemo's in placenta, ca since it went out of business decades ago) it would be this tomato, basil, mozzarella sand which on that perfect bread!  Just the perfect amount of seasoning.....I want one now!!!  Love how one can get a sandwich there and a drunk from lux and enjoy the patio!

The word on the street was this is the place to get great food... Well it was hard to find a place to park to begin with the line was out the door when you finally get inside you're packed into a small lobby... I do not like to feel confused when ordering something it was a cluster I ended up ordering the Soppressata with Aged Provolone & Roasted Peppers sandwich once I ordered I went to the back to do what everyone else was doing playing with their iPhones thank you once again iPhone for making me feel part of a group lol. Once my order was call I go to find a seat and there were none but one with a screaming kid next to it pass! So I ate it in the car to find out after all that it was just an ok sandwich. I will not be back to this spot anytime soon.

So during my trip to Phoenix my friend took me to Pizzeria Bianco, so she thought it appropriate to take me to Pane Bianco the following day for lunch.  Although I was in grave danger of carb and dairy overload, I agreed.  Pane Bianco did not disappoint.  I got the Soppresata, and the bread was A-MAY-ZINNNNNG.  Perfect ratio of meat, cheese, and red pepper inside.  The sandwich is gargantuan - it could easily feed two people.  Which is of course why I finished the whole thing myself.  I was hurtin' for many hours afterward, but I have a problem with this thing called portion control...*shrugs*.  Bottom line: delicioso - oh, yeah, and no wait like it's Pizzeria sister!

After my same-sex date and I sat down at the bar, it took more than 10 minutes (I was watching the clock) before the waiter first addressed us and only AFTER serving an opposite-sex couple who had sat down next to us FIVE minutes later.  I was very disappointed that we weren't served in the order in which we arrived.  We had gone to Pizzera Bianco the previous weekend and thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of the dining experience.  So, we had similarly high expectations for the Pane Bianco cafe.  We were disappointed.  If we weren't starving, we would've gone elsewhere.  We're not entirely sure that the unsatisfactory service was the result of our sexual orientation, but it was very suspicious.  The food was great, however, but we are certain that we will think twice before going to any more of the Bianco's restaurants.

I can only speak to one food item here, and that's their tomato and mozzarella sandwich.  If they only served one sandwich, and I had to eat it for the rest of my life, then I would die a happy and full man.  

We spent our honeymoon in Italy, traveling around the country and eating as if we had gone hungry the other 30 years of our life, and I swear this sandwich matches, and occasionally exceeds, the simple fare that was so overwhelmingly good across the country.  The sandwich is huge, and every time I think I'll have some leftover for later, and each time I prove myself wrong by eating every last crumb and wayward tomato.  One day I'll order something else, but then maybe I won't.
They have the same Pizza at night as Pizzeria Bianco without the wait. I had the Sonny Boy and it was delicious!

Nice place to try a different kinda of sandwich if you're tired of chains like Subway. I love their Housemade Mozzarella, Local Tomato & Basil : food was fresh and the bread was excellent. I also tried the Tuna with Red Onion, Gaeta Olives, Lemon & Arugula and that was nice as well.

Service/seating was really quick (went on a Saturday for lunch). Only complaint is the parking, had to park on the street a couple blocks down because their lot was packed.

First impressions: super hip decor. Noticed right away they had some interesting beer on tap, so I broke my "no beer before 3pm" rule and had a dark IPA. I had the housemade mozzarella salad, and my mother got the sandwich. Both were incredibly delicious, and I could tell the cheese was freshly-made. The basil was pungent and pristine (no holes in the leaves or discoloring), and the EVO they used was obviously fairly high quality. Yes, it's a very simple dish, but the quality of the ingredients is what counts. I give them full marks on both quality and presentation. And for the price, they gave me enough food to completely fill myself up. I left a bit bloated, but I would have definitely ate more had they set another plate of that delicious mozzarella in front of me. I seriously can't overstate how fantastic the cheese was. And they had fresh (not dried or old) whole black peppercorns on the table to grind onto the salad! They tasted almost as good as the pepper we used to get fresh right off the trees in our backyard.

Really impressed with the quality of the ingredients here. It's too bad I don't find myself in downtown Phoenix more often, because I'd love to try the rest of the menu.

Excellent service and very fast. There's a small selection of local beers on tap, which I like and a small menu of sandwiches and salads. We had the chicken salad sandwich and the prosciutto sandwich and both came with a tiny slaw on the side. Everything was excellent. I think our bill total for the two sandwiches and 2 beers was around $40. Beers were pricey at $6 each a pint, but they are a buck or two cheaper at Happy Hour.  Sandwiches are tasty and fresh healthy ingredients.
Stumbled upon this place for lunch. Lucky me.

fantastic sandwiches on fresh baked bread, right off the light rail. they serve some of the same famous pies/ dishes as Pizzeria Bianco with less of a wait/ busy room. definitely hit this up!

only reasons it doesnt get the full 5 stars: limited menu, every time i want to try the deserts they are out of the flavors i want. other than that, love it. the caprese sandwich is one of the best in town!

I have eaten almost everything on Pane Bianco's menu! Their market sandwiches never disappoint; the flavors in the  slow roasted pork are crazy good, the mozarella  sooo fresh, you feel like  thanking the cow. My favorite pizza is a tie between the rosa and bianco verde - 2 entirely different pizza experiences. One features pistachios and caramelized onion(rosa) and the other,  arugula atop amazing cheese.  Both put me in an exceptionally good mood and I relish every single biteI have no idea how they make everything so delicious but keep the magic going! An added plus? The rice pudding is unbelievable and the hospitality they show their customers sets the bar! Every star, well deserved! These people have my respect!

Next to Lux - and nice to go to after a caffeine sugar high from a Soy Mocha. Friend and I got the Mozzarella sandwich. The bread was delicious and it came with a freshly made side cabbage salad (which I think changes each day/week). I recommend asking for some balsamic vinaigrette on the side. The sandwich is even better when you dip in that. Sorry to modify, but really, it's like a caprese on a sandwich. Just needs it! 


Staff seems to be all guys. Maybe just every time I go... but they are always super friendly. Great Vibe. 

Note: Not a ton of vegetarian/vegan nor gluten free options unfortunately.

Totally expect to get my ass kicked by the serious Pane Bianco devotees on here, but oh well. Meh. I don't like paying $10+ for a sandwich, and then almost $4 for a side, and $2-3 for a bottle of water/bottle of soda. That is not an acceptable lunch option to me. Especially when I have yet to patron Pane Bianco one time and not been hungry an hour later. This is the freakin' sushi bar of the sandwich world.

While I'll agree that the ingredients are fresh, you get so few of them it would be difficult to know otherwise. I've been several times now and pretty much always get the tomato/mozz sandwich as I don't eat tuna salad or have a taste for sopressatta. The other day however I got the market sandwich and I was so excited to be able to try something new because it had turkey in it. 2 whole super thin supermarket looking slices of turkey. Mmmmmm. Delicious giant pieces of bread with two super thin slices of turkey in the middle. How could I say anything nasty about paying $10 for you? How dare I be hungry an hour later when you made me so full with all of that bread? You get the picture. Stick the the tomato/mozz sandwich if you're heading this way. Oh, and make sure someone else is picking up this ludicrous tab.

When I lived a block from Pane Bianco, I used to make it a point to spend (and eat) as little as possible throughout the week just to be able to grab one of their sandwiches (preferably the mozzarella, tomato and basil sandwich) on the weekend.

A little pricey, but worth every penny; the food is crafted so well that you start to dream about it and wonder when you can run back for more. If you're a coffee or tea fan, it's perfectly paired with Lux right next door; ample seating to eat your sandwich in peace and enjoy the people watching.

I am not on the Chris Bianco bandwagon. I think his pizza is ok, but not nearly worth an hour wait, let alone the 3 to 4 hour actual wait. But one thing that MF can make better than anyone else is fresh mozzarella. I love mozzarella.

So, without the wait, I can head to Pane Bianco and get a mozzarella sandwich with fresh basil and tomatoes on Bianco's fresh baked bread (it all sounds very fresh).

Don't ask me about any other sandwich because I don't know. Nor do I care. Fresh mozzarella. Some people talk about the goat cheese sandwich. Who cares? Fresh mozzarella!

Most people think of pizza when they hear Chris Bianco. All I can think of is fresh mozzarella.

Location location location! This place is in a great spot for lunch goers and church goes and coffee lovers. its right off the lightrail and across from two churches that I know of, AND next door to lux. You could even get your bike tuned at the Slippery Pig while you eat!

 Its got the cutest "i got all this stuff at a yardsale and upcycled it into voila" amazing furniture! The wait staff was friendly and the food was delish! 

I ordered the soup made with seasonal veggies. My son was in the mood for meatball sandwich probably because he smelled the special "Sloppy Giuseppe" brewing! He ordered that and was mega pleased. its exactly like a meatball sub only its not. =D Instead of meatballs its like a meat sauce with more meat and less sauce. 

We'll definitely be back.
I want my house to look like this place. I absolutely loved everything. The mozzarella sandwich was AMAZING. Quick service, simple menu.

Pane Bianco has long been a fav of mine for lunch. What's not to love about fresh baked bread, great ingredients prepared in the typical Italian way-simple, fresh, uncluttered.
We were excited to try the newly expanded dine in Pane Bianco and were quite frankly disappointed. 
First off, the interior and ambiance are great-no problems there.
But, it was only 7pm and they were out of 3 of their dishes-so we went with a pizza-3 cheese and arugula and a special-pasta fagioli-a very popular peasant fare that when made well is sublime.
The pizza was okay- a little dry, actually, and I have to admit the pasta was also just okay. I expected a slightly tomato broth with lots of garlic and firm beans with small pasta-more like a soup-what I got was a bland plate of rigatoni with mashed beans. No parmesan even to round out the dish.
I think Pane Bianco has some growing pains before it reaches a stellar status and I am confident it will. I suspect it was just an off night.

I love this place. Everyone I know raves about it, and every item I try is out of this world! I recommended it to a friend, unfortunately he doesn't understand the appeal of fresh authentic ingredients and the rustic charm of the place. He's missing out!

We just fell In love with Pane Bianco. How could you not? Well on a very warm summer day my wife and I stopped off at Lux coffee next door for coffee. While drinking our coffee the suggestion was brought up to go try Pane Biance. Why not. 

We walked in and sat at the bar after we made sure we could bring in our coffees. I really liked the old style farm house decor of the restaurant. So simple, yet done so classy. It welcomed you inside. 

We both were not super hungry but decided to share a sandwich. I don't remember the name but it was the only one with Italian meat. 

Wow, simple, but amazing. We loved it, the bread was just the perfect amount if chewy put soft and the sandwich had flavored thanks to the I taipan meat and onions. Also the sandwich was super big so the 2 if us easily shared and were satisfied. 

Service from the bartender was very good and polite. I'd love to come back and try more. I'm giving it 5 stars because I know Bianco put a lot of his heart and soul in his businesses and they have never I disappointed me. And for the fact the sandwich hit the spot and we enjoyed the bartenders company. We will totally be back soon to Pane Bianco!

Just popped in for a drink while we waited next door to be seated, but definatley want to return. The place is a converted house that looks about a hundred years old. The barkeep was cool and seemed very knowledgeable about his craft, however there were only three tap. I saw a pile of board games so I liked it immediately! Also, happy hour is from 3-7 so our order was only eight bucks. Neat little place :-)

Lately I have been addicted to a good Caprese style sandwich and Pane Bianco's is AWESOME!  I read the previous reviews so I went there expecting a crowd and nowhere to sit.  This did not detract from the experience for me because the quality and freshness of the food was more than enough to get and keep my attention.  The staff were very friendly and helpful, being from the Atlantic Northeast I have high expectations when it comes to Italian done well with personality to boot. I did not want to wait till I got home to eat my so good smelling prize so I went outside to find picnic style tables and benches.  It was way to hot to sit outside and I was craving iced coffee so I went next door to Lux and was both surprised and relieved to find many of their patrons with Pane Bianco bags openly eating their lunches with drinks from Lux to claim patronage.  Can't wait for a hopefully air-conditioned expansion.

Since a friend of mine took me there a couple weeks ago, I've gone back 4 times. The atmosphere is unique, with outdoor picnic-style seating. I didn't have difficulty in finding a place to sit down during their crowded lunch time (11-3), and everyone is cordial enough.
I agree with everyone here about the Mozzarella/tomato/basil sandwich being the best. As a meat lover, I also like their Soppressata sandwich (with aged provolone and roasted peppers).
And there's Lux cafe right next door. Top notch sandwich place!

This place is unbelievable!  The man and I were out and about and stopped off at Lux for some coffee.  While we were outside enjoying the GORGEOUS weather we finally have, he noticed the sign that they had margherita pizza, so we decided to give it a try.  And we're so glad we did!!  This place is i.n.c.r.e.d.i.b.l.e. for the following reasons:  
1:  She spoke to the chef in italian when she told him our order.
2:  Our order came quickly and she offered to bring it outside instead of us having to wait for it.
3:  We got a Coke and a Sprite, which was actually Mexican Coke and Sprite in the bottles made with actual sugar instead of high fructose corn syrup and they were cold and delicious!
4:  Everything she brought us from the plates to the silverware is environmentally friendly.
5: She brought two little pieces of homemade chocolate with toffee in it.
6: Now what you've been waiting for...  The pizza.  We were a little hesitant about the crust just by looking at it, but one bite in, we were in love.  The crust was flavorful and light and crispy but not too crispy with a hint of sweetness and that glorious wood-stone oven flavor.  You could tell that the marinara sauce was homemade and it tasted like they'd picked the tomatoes fresh from their garden that morning.  The mozzarella  had just enough pull to melt in your mouth instead of getting caught in your throat and the basil was fresh and glorious.  It was seriously the best pizza I've ever had.  

If you're in the mood for something authentic, fresh and AMAZING, go to Pane Bianco.  Support this locally owned business.  You won't be disappointed.

Been here a couple times now and have been pleasantly surprised both times. I've had the Housemade Mozzarella and a special Prosciutto sandwich. Both were delicious and the bread is out of this world. I am not overly impressed with the service, but the food will bring me back. Chris Bianco produces some pretty delicious food!

It is simple.  The best ingredients put together in the best possible way.  The menu is very limited so don't take a picky eater here.  The bread is amazing.

Love to go there for lunch to get a sandwich, and now they are open for dinner where you can get a pizza without having to brave the craziness of Pizzeria Bianco.

Exceptional Italian sandwiches like no other you have ever tried. I cannot compare to anything from Italy as I have never traveled there, but I am sold on the authenticity at Pane Bianco. 

The menu is limited but it allows them to knock it out of the park on what they do offer. The flat bread is made right there in the oven central to the shop, and tastes great, there seems to be a pinch of salt tossed on at the very end that gives the bread a great finish. 

The sandwich I enjoyed was filled with sopressata and mozzarella which ranked with the best I have ever had. 

All around an extremely worth while stop for anyone who loves Italian deli food, Do not pass on the candy that comes with the meal!

Updating a previous review.  My primary interest here is getting Bianco pizzas to go.  The menu has 4 of the 6 pizzas that are featured at Pizzeria Bianco plus a market pizza.  In my previous review I had expressed severe displeasure with the fact that although they do carryout orders they will not take orders over the phone.  I think that is a flaw, and should at least be better communicated.  

Anyway, this time I called in advance and found out what the market pizza was (smoked mozzarella and sopresata), and asked them what the typical wait time was.  I was told about 10 minutes, which seems very reasonable.  I drove over there (it is only about 2.5 miles from my house) and put in my order for a Magherita and a Rosa.  There was some in-door seating available (it was a bit too cold to wait at the outside tables) so I sat and waited.  Chris Bianco came by and we had a nice chat.  My pizzas were indeed ready in less than 10 minutes.  I actually lost a couple of minutes when they failed to notice that they were to-go orders and put them out for table delivery.  They were a little colder than they should have been because of this, but the new setup (with seating in the part where Lux once was) was only in its first week, so I ave them the benefit of the doubt.  The pizza was wonderful, I had just partaken of a Rosa at Pizzeria Bianco about 3 weeks earlier and could not see any difference.

I am withholding one star due to the phone order issue and the screwup on the to-go order, but this is the deal:

Pizzeria Bianco has what the NY Times claimed to be among the best pizzas in the country.  You have to wait an hour or two for a table.

Pane Bianco has the same pizza, and you can have one, either to eat in or take out, in about 10 minutes.

Specials Tonight at Pane Bianco 

*Lasagna al Forno $18 (Serves 3) 
*Farinata $6 whole $3 half
*Arugala Salad with Peaches $7
*Meatballs in tomato sauce $12
*Roasted Vegetables $7 
*Ribollita Soup $6

More than worth it to come out. 

Open until 8pm

I think Mr. C said it best "I'm not overwhelmed or underwhelmed just whelmed."  This place had me confused. The setting is comfortable, trendy and hip. The ingredients were all fresh and tasty. The service was fine. But... Altogether I wasn't impressed. Both of us couldn't put our finger on it but it wasn't that great. 

We went for lunch and the menu doesn't have very many options which isn't a big deal to me. I ordered the mozzarella basil sandwich because while simple it's one of my favorites. I enjoyed the sandwich but I was like ummmm okay whatever. The problem is this place isn't cheap. I think my sandwich was $10 and Mr. C's was $12 and it was just a sandwich nothing else and nothing crazy special. Where's the chips or pickle or something?

I'm still looking forward to trying pizza Bianca. Our server did say they actually do have pizza here in the evenings without the wait although I want to try the real thing.

Oh Pane, you stole my heart. Not only was your service spectacular, your staff was nice, attentive and prompt. We had about 15-20 people come in at 2:45pm unknowing that you were closing at 3pm for a reserved event. You served all of us promptly without one mess up on an order. The food was ridiculously great and the water/drinks were always being filled or asked if another beer would be liked. I ordered the mozzarella sandwich which came on a warm focaccia bread... it was such a nice touch. The mozzarella was fresh and ample. The basil was fresh without any dents, blackening on corner leaves or bruising from being ripped/chopped- any of the such that often arrives on such sandwiches. 

The décor is very anthropologie bohemian chic... so cozy. I can't wait to frequent you again next time I'm in phx. You lived up to all the raving reviews friends have told me.

Setting:  Very small, quaint place.  Seating are all located outside.  Nice area with parking lot, which is a plus.  Very clean.

Food:  Very yummy.  We tried all their sandwiches and they were all good.  I especially liked the tuna...highly recommended.  And all the drinks are unique.

Service:  We came practically at closing time.  They only had a few breads left, and they accommodated our group of 6 just fine.  Very nice folks.

Tried this place for the first time today. Was looking for a good place to grab lunch before dropping some friends off at the airport.

Like a lot of the places in the Central/downtown area the building is nothing to look at but is well decorated inside. 

The menu was really simple but the waiter let us know of a few ways to mix it up and I ended up with a Mozzarella sandwich with Soppressata on Focaccia. It was really, really good.

The Mozzarella and the Focaccia are made in house which was an added bonus.

The staff were friendly and helpful. The menu and bar was limited but the quality was high. It was no surprise to figure out this place is affiliated with Pizzeria Bianco.

One downside is that it is on the pricy side, but considering how fresh the food was it was just about acceptable.

I will be returning.
Wooooah! Sandwiches so great! And the inside is cool. Great lunch spot. I have not had sandwich this good since.  Soooooo goood
The farmer salad, the bread, and then the pizza. Who says you can't get great pizza outside of NY. Great meal. Worth a drive.

I love Pane Bianco. Their Mozzarella tomato sandwich is simply delicious. Their bread taste so good which makes the sandwich well worth it.  I've been here several times and not one time have I been even remotely disappointed.

Where do I begin? If the food is from Chris Bianco you know it's going to be good,  but was tad dissapointed at our antipasto plate. It was rather ordinary and sparse compared to any of the dozen or so times I've had it at Bianco downtown. We also ordered the Rosa which is one of their signature pizza pies with cheese, onion and Arizona pistachios. Delicious. We also thought wine would be a nice choice. Unfortunately, they don't have their liquor license sorted out yet. So a hit and a two misses. 

But here's the main reason they only got two stars:
